LEAD: These are tumultuous times for the Ranger players, with the team saddled with nine more players than it can protect in next Monday's waiver draft. Yesterday, that tumult cost George McPhee, Terry Carkner and Jeff Jackson their jobs and it delivered John Ogrodnick from Quebec.

LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds rose in the week ended yesterday, marking yet another rise in an advance that has lasted more than a month.
LEAD: The foreign ministers of Israel and China met for the first time today and agreed to maintain regular contacts between their two governments at the United Nations.

LEAD: OPERA AT THE ACADEMY was founded in March 1985 and is devoted to the training of singers and actors, the presentation of contemporary productions of the classics and, eventually, the creation of new works of music theater.

LEAD: California telephone operating company, said today that it would issue up to 15 million common shares in Pactel Personal Communications, the company's cellular telephone and paging unit. LEAD: Australia's Hooker Corporation would acquire 80 percent of financially beleaguered Sakowitz Inc., the Houston-based retailer, under an amended plan of organization filed in Federal Bankruptcy Court. LEAD: ''FIFTY, 60, 70 years ago, the gypsy used to come around and pick up pots and re-tin them,'' said Fred Bridge, owner of the Bridge Kitchenware Corporation. Since gypsies no longer roam the streets, the household cook must find this service elsewhere.

LEAD: A twin-engine airplane with six people aboard crashed in heavy fog today while attempting to land at the Tijuana airport, killing everyone aboard, the authorities said. LEAD: The City Council voted Tuesday night to ban the sale of realistic-looking toy guns. The 4-to-1 vote came six weeks after a man using such a toy ordered David Horowitz, the television consumer reporter, to read a bizarre statement on the air.

LEAD: The 63-year-old New Yorker magazine, under new ownership since May 1985, is raising its circulation rate base by 20,000 with its Jan. 4 issue. It will be the largest increase in the history of the magazine and will bring the total to 545,000, a 3.8 percent rise.

LEAD: Stock prices rose sharply yesterday as the new quarter began with a surge of investor interest in blue-chip and technology issues and growing expectations that forthcoming earnings reports would be strong.

LEAD: * National Medical Enterprises Inc. is offering $81 million of Baa-1/BBB+ rated 9.40 percent extendible notes due 1990 at a price of 98.678 to yield 9.92 percent through underwiters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. With a put and call date of 1990, the company has the option of extending the maturity out to 1999.

LEAD: Hill Samuel Group P.L.C., the beleaguered British merchant bank, appears to be ready to succumb to a bid involving a takeover followed by an auction of various parts of the business, according to London bankers and analysts.
LEAD: American Brands Inc., a diversified company based in Old Greenwich, Conn., said yesterday that it plans to sell its Sunshine Biscuits and Pinkerton's subsidiaries.
LEAD: Are the Democrats going to throw away their chances in the 1988 Presidential election?
LEAD: Sometime soon the Soviet Union will release most of its political prisoners. That is the expectation in the Reagan Administration, although Washington has said nothing public about it yet.
LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the Russians had taken ''a significant step forward'' in agreeing in principle to discuss a possible arms embargo against Iran.

LEAD: The Cowdin Stakes at Belmont Park tomorrow is New York's third Grade I race this year for 2-year-olds, and the third with a surprisingly small field.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation plans to bring out a line of work stations for engineers and scientists that will initially be incompatible with its new personal computer line, a senior company official said yesterday.

LEAD: A Delaware judge said today that he would rule next week on whether to grant a preliminary injunction to stop maneuvering by the Newmont Mining Corporation and its British ally. They are trying to thwart an unfriendly takeover effort led by T. Boone Pickens, the Texas oilman.

LEAD: Members of Issei Fubi Street Theater Troupe performing in Washington Square Park. The troupe, which mixes traditional avant-garde theater, is to have a more formal debut Sunday at the Apollo Theater.

LEAD: With humor and resignation, members of the Century Association, one of Manhattan's oldest and most exclusive male clubs, voted overwhelmingly last night to admit women, if a city law barring discrimination in public accommodations was held constitutional.

LEAD: Assets of the nation's 400 money market mutual funds decreased $707.5 million, to $243.75 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 106 institutional funds were down $111.2 million, to $64.28 billion. Assets of the 201 general-purpose funds were up $165.6 million, to $72.06 billion.

LEAD: While most celebrations of the United States Constitution involve a kind of self-congratulation, the celebration by the Smithsonian Museum, ''A More Perfect Union: Japanese Americans and the U.S. Constitution,'' which opened today, is just the opposite.

LEAD: AC&R/DHB & Bess, a Saatchi & Saatchi company with great strengths in the retail area, has become the agency for the Zayre Discount Department Stores Corporation, based in Framingham, Mass.

LEAD: Riverside Park needs green. Not green as in grass, but green as in greenbacks.

LEAD: A four-foot-tall toy sheep is ensconced in an antique chair at the entrance to Susan Keane's living room. Above the doorway hangs a lamb marionette. Tiny sheep are tucked into peg holes in the overhead beams. Wooden and ceramic versions stand on tables and windowsills. The rug has a blackface sheep's image in the pattern.

LEAD: Boxing Stackhouse Retains Title: Ricky Stackhouse of Atlanta retained his Continental Americas middleweight championship when he won a unanimous 12-round decision from Kevin Moley of Selden, L.I., at the Felt Forum last night. A bout between Pernell Whitaker, the undefeated lightweight, and Mark Brannon was canceled when the New York State Athletic Commission did not pass Brannon for medical reasons.

LEAD: Slowly, David Simpson ticked off the list of casualties. There were Cosgriff's Hotel, Barrett's Clothing Store, Taco Johns, KQZR radio, Grako Tires, Jer's Liquor Store, Action Video and Polich Brothers Auto Parts.

LEAD: An official state booklet on high school dropouts has become the center of a dispute among many New York educators, who say it implies that black students are less capable of learning than whites.
LEAD: Benito Santiago of San Diego got his first major league bunt single at an opportune time.

LEAD: New York City will build a new home for one of its premier high schools, Stuyvesant, in time for the start of the 1991-92 school year under a schedule that seeks to show that its public schools can be built fast and well, Mayor Koch and Governor Cuomo said yesterday.
LEAD: Maybe the most intriguing characterization of all during this N.F.L. players' strike came from Texas E. Schramm, president of the Dallas Cowboys football team.
LEAD: The verbal feuding between Mark Gastineau and his striking Jets teammates escalated into a shoving match this morning.
LEAD: Telephone bills across New York State will be printed in ''plain language'' under an agreement reached between New York Telephone and the State Public Service Commission.

LEAD: As the games dwindle to a precious few, it's time to take note of the unique brand of information and entertainment that Tim McCarver has once again brought to Mets telecasts. And to recognize that he pays a price for his refreshing candor.

LEAD: The United States has protested two Soviet long-range missile tests this week that sent unarmed warheads into the Pacific Ocean about 600 miles northwest of Hawaii, the State Department said today.

LEAD: The Detroit Tigers moved within one game of first-place Toronto heading into their season-ending showdown as Alan Trammell had three hits, including his 200th of the season, in a 9-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles tonight.

LEAD: Salvadoran rebel leaders, angered at a remark by El Salvador's President, have postponed a meeting scheduled for Sunday with Government officials to discuss ways to carry out a new regional peace plan.

LEAD: The Rotterdam Philharmonic, conducted by James Conlon, is to perform works by Tchaikovsky, Martinu and Rachmaninoff Sunday at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall, with Bella Davidovich as the piano soloist. Tickets are $14 to $25. Information: 247-7800.

LEAD: TROMA INC., the small independent company responsible for outstandingly irreverent features made on budgets that are lower than low, is in a good position to make films that are cheap, impudent and funny. But two out of three won't do. And ''Surf Nazis Must Die'' isn't funny in the slightest, the title notwithstanding.

LEAD: Art Blakey, a drummer, and the Jazz Messengers are appearing tonight through Sunday at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

LEAD: THE first time around in adaptations of several Dorothy L. Sayers stories, Lord Peter Wimsey was played by Ian Carmichael and seen on public television's ''Masterpiece Theater.'' Now the monocled aristocrat and haughty sleuth is being portrayed, far more authentically, by Edward Petherbridge and, beginning tomorrow at 9 P.M.
LEAD: The Senate Appropriations Committee today approved legislation that would ban smoking on all domestic airline flights of two hours or less and impose penalties on violators.
LEAD: The Irving Bank Corporation sent a letter to its shareholders yesterday that said the bank would fight a hostile takeover bid made by the Bank of New York Corporation.

LEAD: The antitrust suit filed yesterday by the National Basketball Players Association called the league's college draft ''one of the longest running continuing restraints on competition for player services.'' A team owns the rights to a player it selects in the draft, and he cannot negotiate with another team.
LEAD: When it was over, the Mets took it without spite or whimper, as they stood in a private box high behind first base in Busch Stadium and watched 48,763 fans roar for the new champions.
LEAD: A retired Columbia University journalism professor has won a long battle to eradicate Government records that labeled him a national security risk.
LEAD: The Cardinals defeated the Montreal Expos by 8-2 last night in St. Louis, clinching the National League East title and ending the Mets' chances of repeating as World Series champions.

LEAD: Although yesterday's California earthquake was a small foretaste of the big one that experts expect there, it apparently had little or no bearing on when that larger earthquake might take place.

LEAD: IBP Inc., the nation's largest producer of fresh beef and pork products, completed one of the largest initial public offerings on record, selling a 47 percent stake in the company for $408.5 million. The Occidental Petroleum Corporation, which bought IBP, based in Dakota City, Neb., in 1981, will continue to maintain control of it.

LEAD: Pat Robertson, the television evangelist who gave up his ministry to run for President, formally declared his candidacy for the Republican nomination yesterday. He made his announcement in front of the Bedford-Stuyvesant brownstone where he lived 27 years ago when he said the Lord called him to minister to the poor.

LEAD: To be 10 years old, to be a Mets fan, to have had your team fighing for the pennant the last weekend of the season - nothing like it. Jason Yeager's jitters have jitters. ''Worried?'' said Jason. ''No! I am a little bit.''

LEAD: What if Gov. Michael Dukakis's Presidential campaign manager, John Sasso, invented a story that Senator Joseph Biden swiped quotes and even personal history from other politicians and passed them off as his own? More, what if Mr. Sasso slyly peddled the story to the media, which then gullibly reported it as true?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Like many other parents here, Elaine Gamble never thought the Chicago school strike would go on so long. For the first two weeks her children stayed home, reading, watching television and pretending, for the most part, that they were still on summer vacation.

LEAD: AS of this coming Sunday, Gluttony will hold court at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Enthroned on a Gothic Revival armchair (newly acquired by the Met) that was made around 1860 for a large and grand town house in Yonkers, he can hold tight to a jeweled orb from the age of Suleyman the Magnificent, which is part of a new and keenly awaited exhibition at the Met.
LEAD: Pope John Paul II opened a Synod of Bishops in St. Peter's Basilica today by asking the prelates to address ''the proper and specific tasks'' assigned to ordinary lay people.

LEAD: Jim Paxson of the Portland Trail Blazers, whose trade to Cleveland this summer was nullified because of an injury to the player he was exchanged for, will undergo toe surgery today. . . . Pat Cash, the Wimbledon champion, has ruled himself out of today's Australia's Davis Cup tennis semifinal against India in Sydney because of a jarred right knee.
LEAD: Persian Gulf, a rock band, will perform tomorrow at 10 P.M. at the Rodeo Bar at Albuquerque, 375 Third Avenue, at 27th Street (683-6500). There is no cover or minimum.
LEAD: There are two prison guards from death row. A player is wearing the number of his brother, who is picketing, and there is a tenor who sings opera in the locker room.
LEAD: Americans are growing older, on the average, with the median age reaching 31.7 years in 1986, up from 30 in 1980, the Census Bureau reports.

LEAD: New York officials videotaped trash in New Jersey and New Jersey officials threw plastic bottles into the Hudson River and other waterways today as both states tried to pinpoint the sources of recent Jersey Shore pollution.

LEAD: Benjamin Grund, a former director and partner in Seidman & Seidman, an international accounting firm based in New York City, died of a heart attack last Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83 years old. In 1920, Mr. Grund was hired as a file clerk by a founding partner of the firm. Two years later, he was made acting head of the New York office's tax department.

LEAD: A profile on Monday of Ann F. Lewis, a strategist for the Democratic Party, quoted Robert S. Strauss, a former national Democratic chairman, as saying that he would vote against Ms. Lewis if she ran for that post because she represented ''a point of view that the Democratic Party must get away from.

LEAD: ''LIKE FATHER LIKE SON'' has a road map of a plot: thanks to an Indian brain-transference serum, a middle-aged doctor and his teen-age son trade minds but not bodies. It's easier to believe such a potion exists than to imagine anyone could make this movie live, but Dudley Moore and Kirk Cameron are so clever and charming as the mismatched pair that they turn a potential dud into a sweetly engaging film.

LEAD: The violinist Stephane Grappelli leads a group tonight through Monday at the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street (475-8592). Sets begin at 8:30 and 10:30 P.M.; there is a $17.50 cover and a $5 minimum.

LEAD: The old man sat down heavily, making the park bench creak, and addressed a remark to a stranger already there. Hesitant for a moment when the other said he did not speak Bulgarian, the man offered a greeting in German.

LEAD: A monthlong series of music and dance performances and seminars devoted to African culture begins tomorrow at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West and 79th Street. Appearing tomorrow will be Kayraba, a West African dance company; Schroeder Cherry, a puppeteer, and Charlotte Ami Amezor, an artist.
LEAD: Bond prices declined modestly yesterday as investors remained inactive amid widespread forecasts of higher interest rates in the future.

LEAD: In the aftermath of an episode that led to his resignation as Presidential campaign manager for Michael S. Dukakis, many political operatives and observers are wondering exactly what it is that John Sasso did wrong.

LEAD: Amid a recovery, the semiconductor industry projects sales growth of 17.9 percent in 1988, to $37.8 billion, an industry committee reported today. Citing substantial growth in application-specific integrated circuits and other new technologies, the committee also forecast sales of $40.6 billion in 1989 and $45 billion in 1990.

LEAD: ''ROZA,'' the new musical at the Royale, overflows with so much gooey humanity that it's easy to leave the theater feeling like W. C. Fields on a misanthropic day: one's first impulse is to find and kick a very small dog.

LEAD: Representatives of women's groups told a House subcommittee today that many men in the military still wanted to exclude women from the armed forces despite their achievements over the last 15 years.
LEAD: A 48-year-old South African, acting as a surrogate for her daughter, gave birth to three grandchildren today.
LEAD: Senator Bob Dole's Presidential campaign has been buoyed by some new support.

LEAD: The Chicago and North Western Transportation Company has agreed to sell 208 miles of track in Wisconsin to the FRVR Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Itel Rail Corporations. A news release by Chicago and North Western's parent company, the Chicago-based CNW Corporation, said final conditions of the $66 million deal remained to be worked out.

LEAD: ELIOT FELD'S ''Embraced Waltzes,'' which had its premiere Wednesday night at the opening of the Feld Ballet's new season at the Joyce Theater, 19th Street and Eighth Avenue, is one of the choreographer's especially imaginative responses to familiar material.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Two Virginia newspapers, citing unidentified sources, have reported that Coach Charles Moir could step down as early as tomorrow as basketball coach at Virginia Tech. ''That is a possibility,'' Moir said by telephone yesterday. Since the university initiated an internal inquiry of the basketball program last spring, observers have predicted Moir would resign.

LEAD: The tease was put to an end tonight. The possible permutations and combinations that had taken place in and around Shea Stadium, the what-ifs and the wishful thinking, are now footnotes to a third St. Louis Cardinal division championship in the last six seasons.

LEAD: Warren Zevon, a pianist, singer and songwriter, and X, a Los Angeles rock band, will perform Sunday at 9 P.M. at the Ritz, 119 East 11th Street (254-2800). Tickets are $17.50 in advance, $18.50 Sunday.

LEAD: A fire set in a Harlem welfare hotel early yesterday injured 29 residents, eight of them critically, and left six families homeless, the authorities said.

LEAD: Canadian officials, on the verge of announcing a final collapse of free-trade talks with the United States, said today that a last-minute proposal by the United States had dramatically changed the situation, opening the way for a resumption of talks in Washington on Friday.

LEAD: A large savings and loan institution that was considering moving its regional headquarters from Manhattan to New Jersey will instead relocate to Queens, New York City officials announced yesterday.
LEAD: Dart Financial Corp., Landover, Md., a division of the Dart Corp., appointed Linda Haft senior vice president.

LEAD: Della Femina, Travisano & Partners will be creating the advertising for Dr. Scholl's line of foot care products. Dr. Scholl, a subsidiary of Schering-Plough, will continue to use Schering's in-house agency, Lake-Spiro-Schurman in Memphis, for all media placements.

LEAD: The fury in Robert M. Hayes's voice is barely under control: It has become clear that he will not get all that he wants from his latest court settlement on behalf of homeless families.

LEAD: A suspect in the killing of the president of New York City's school custodians union died yesterday at Jacobi Hospital in the Bronx of complications after brain surgery, a hospital official said.

LEAD: Betty Carter and her trio, the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street (228-7880). Betty Carter, the Brooklyn-based jazz singer with a rich, elastic alto and a be-bop background, never sings the same song twice in quite the same way. Her iconoclastic interpretations turn familiar standards into psychic explorations in which bent notes, meditative pauses, lightning accelerated passages, and abrupt changes in timbre virtually reinvent the material.

LEAD: Gospel, jazz and Latin music will be featured during a weekend of free outdoor performances at the West 125th Pier, at the Hudson River. LEAD: The City and County of Honolulu offered $50 million of general obligation bonds yesterday through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities.

LEAD: The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund wound up their joint annual meeting today on an optimistic note, invigorated with new approaches for coping with global debt.

LEAD: The membership of the Advertising Club of New York, concerned about the number of unemployed agency people over 45 who are the unfortunate victims of industry shrinkage, is beginning a program to do something about it.

LEAD: Back on the Streets A reader in Managua with a copy of La Presna, with the headline ''The People Triumph,'' as the Nicaraguan opposition newspaper resumed publication yesterday. Page A3. Trade Talks to Resume After a last-minute proposal by the United States, Canada said its negotiators would return to Washington to resume free-trade talks.
LEAD: A student on the Columbia campus said that if Barnard suited up a football team, it could beat Columbia.

LEAD: Nearly 300 top book editors and publishers in New York and Boston have sent a letter to members of the Senate Judiciary Committee opposing the nomination of Judge Robert H. Bork to the Supreme Court.
LEAD: The embattled opposition newspaper La Prensa was back on the streets today, 451 days after it was shut by the Sandinista Government.

LEAD: The dB's,Go Betweens and Dash Rip Rock, the Ritz, 11th Street between Third and Fourth Avenues (254-2800). The dB's play pop-rock with Southern roots and ''Rubber Soul''-Big Star influences; Go Betweens, from Australia, play their own thoughtful, gently lyrical pop-rock blend. Both bands have plenty of indelible songs, and Dash Rip Rock, Georgia-based newcomers, have songs of their own, plus energy.

LEAD: The Dean Foods Company, which was started in 1925 as a maker of evaporated milk, has named a third-generation Dean as chief executive. He is Howard M. Dean, who has been serving as president and chief operating officer.

LEAD: ONE of the most important collections of Dutch and Flemish Old Master paintings formed in this country in recent years - including works by Frans Hals, Jan Davidsz de Heem, Jan Jansz den Uyl and Jacob van Ruisdael - will be auctioned at Sotheby's in January.

LEAD: A key Republican Senator and three Southern Democrats today announced their opposition to Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination to the Supreme Court, a development raising serious doubts about his chances for confirmation.
LEAD: A mobile home park can deny housing to families with children under 18 years old, the California Supreme Court ruled unanimously today.
LEAD: An investment group consisting of Entertainment Marketing Inc. and Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P., disclosed that it had raised its stake in Crazy Eddie Inc. to 15.6 percent, from 14.6 percent.

LEAD: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M., Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee (Working Group on Migrant Workers' Rights) - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Administrative and Budgetary Committee - 10 A.M. Legal Committee - 10 A.M. Council for Namibia - 3:30 P.M.

LEAD: Nancy Reagan following James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, through an obstacle course at the National Center for Therapeutic Riding. Mrs. Reagan was at the center to present a $5,000 check from the Nancy Reagan Drug Abuse Foundation.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Nina Ricci has assigned its fragrances to O'Rielly, O'Brien, Clow/ RSCG, a French-owned New York agency whose parent company handles the brands abroad.

LEAD: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, grim-faced and still shaken by the loss of his top adviser, today began the job of repairing the damage his Presidential campaign suffered from its role in a rival's downfall.

LEAD: The United States Government agreed today to charter a 264,000-ton oil tanker to the company that manages Kuwait's oil traffic in the Persian Gulf. It is the first ship manned by American citizens to be added to the Kuwaiti vessels qualifying for naval escorts there.

LEAD: Ping-Hsun Chang, a former Chinese diplomat and consul general of the Republic of China in New York City for more than a decade after World War II, died of a heart attack Sept. 14 at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei, Taiwan. He was 84 years old and lived in Taipei.

LEAD: The Interior Department's Bureau of Reclamation, which for 85 years built the dams and water projects that spurred the development of the American West, today announced a radical change in its mission.
LEAD: A judge ruled yesterday that New York City must continue to abide by a consent decree setting sanitary standards for shelters where it houses more than 9,000 homeless men and women every night.
LEAD: The Bankers Trust Company is offering $100 million of 9 percent deposit notes due in 1989 at a price of 99.85, to yield 9.08 percent, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc.

LEAD: European Travel & Life, acquired a year and a half ago by Murdoch Magazines, is increasing its circulation rate base to 230,000, from 200,000, with the January issue and will then add another 100,000 to that, according to John B. Evans, president of the company.

LEAD: Three girls and a woman were killed and 35 people were injured when thousands of fans stormed a gate at an outdoor concert, the city Attorney General's office said today. The stampede took place late Wednesday afternoon before a concert by three of Mexico's most popular pop-music groups at the city's Sports Palace.
LEAD: Law reviews, the student-edited magazines produced by law schools, are known less for relevance than for examining arcane legal subjects.

LEAD: Tommy Flanagan, a pianist, is leading a trio with George Mraz on bass and Al Foster on drums tonight through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, below 11th Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.
LEAD: One of the highest minimum wages in the nation, $3.75 an hour, took effect in Connecticut today, along with a new law greatly expanding the kinds of jobs that 15-year-olds can hold.

LEAD: Accreditation was returned to Zoo Atlanta today. The American Association of Zoological Parks and Aquariums, which lifted the zoo's accreditation in 1984, restored it after the zoo met all the agency's requirements in an inspection last month. Zoo Atlanta has spent millions of dollars on repairs and renovation, hired a veterinarian and made other changes.
LEAD: Senator Rudy Boschwitz is an incurable matchmaker.

LEAD: THE special thing about Harry Ironminster, the hero of ''The Right Hand Man,'' is that he suffers from diabetes. It's 1860, when languishing figures of fiction usually expired from weak lungs, but this is Australia.
LEAD: Some of the finest plays in the game are extremely simple, but since they run against instinct some creative imagination is needed.

LEAD: Crewmen aboard the 43,000-ton Pakistani tanker Johar showing damage after two Iranian speedboats opened fire with machine guns and rockets. No casualties were reported and the damage was minor. Two Japanese ships were attacked by Iranians on Wednesday. In an attack by Iraqi warplanes, the Australian captain of a shrimp boat was killed when a missile struck his boat.

LEAD: In an event laden with symbolism, President Reagan is expected to confer at the White House Monday with Joaquim A. Chissano, the President of Mozambique, who will be in Washington on a private visit.

LEAD: Parents who say Halloween celebrates paganism and the ''dark side'' have persuaded an elementary school to ban traditional Halloween activities this year. Instead, the 641 children at Coal Creek Elementary in Louisville will celebrate the 200th anniversary of the United States Constitution. The principal, Ellen Goering, said Wednesday that colonial dress would be the only costume permitted Oct.
LEAD: International
LEAD: Peter Sellars, the 29-year-old director who is fond of shocking theater audiences, has been named director of the biennial Los Angeles Festival.

LEAD: Stewart's teammate, Reggie Jackson, leaving no doubt about his intentions to quit, punctuated his final game at the Oakland Coliseum yesterday with a base hit off an 0-2 pitch as a pinch-hitter in the Athletics' eighth inning. Jackson then threw waves and kisses to a standing, cheering crowd. Jackson, 41 years old, said he was not making an official announcement of his retirement after 20 seasons, but he never made it so definite as he did yesterday.
LEAD: The Soviet Union has complied with a United States order to further cut the size of its United Nations missions by today, according to American officials.

LEAD: A 21-year-old Staten Island man with a criminal record as a sex offender was charged yesterday with raping a 15-year-old girl on the island in June, and is also a suspect in the slayings of two women there in the last three weeks, the authorities said.
LEAD: The A. H. Robins Company asked a Federal bankruptcy court yesterday for authorization to sign a final merger agreement with Rorer Group Inc.
LEAD: Glass Eye, from Austin, Tex., and Blue Movie, from San Francisco, will play a rock double bill tonight at 9 and 11 at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055). Admission is $6.

LEAD: KURT SANDERLING first led the New York Philharmonic in 1984 and must have impressed someone in authority at that time. The German conductor, much of whose career was pursued in the Soviet Union and East Berlin, returned to the orchestra last evening to begin a two-week guest engagement. He is not by any means a keg of excitement.

LEAD: Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat stays mail carriers from the swift completion of their appointed rounds. Nor will they stay firefighters from performing their essential duty. But the elements will stop a New York City firefighter from inspecting a potentially dangerous building.

LEAD: Sixty-four people were arrested yesterday when narcotics officers raided five buildings on West 164th Street and Amsterdam Avenue in Washington Heights at about 4:30 P.M. Most were charged with possession and sale of cocaine, the police said. The raids were at 562, 559, 548 and 505 West 164th Street and at 2091 Amsterdam Avenue.

LEAD: Whatever happened while Mikhail Gorbachev was mysteriously out of sight for nearly two months, he is back and things are starting to happen in the East again. So far they are mostly words, and such startling words that the temptation is to write them off as the familiar extravagance of Communist Party propaganda.

LEAD: THIS week Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d proposed to lay another brick in the foundation of a new world monetary system - a gold brick. The United States, he told the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, is ready to consider using, as an ''additional indicator'' for guiding the coordination of national economic policies, ''a basket of commodities, including gold.
LEAD: Orders to factories fell 1.7 percent in August as lower demand for aircraft and military goods brought the first setback in manufacturing since January.
LEAD: Warwick Advertising said yesterday that it had resigned the Calvin Cooler business, which bills about $2 million.
LEAD: The Senate voted Wednesday to allow insurance companies to deny insurance to people in the District of Columbia who test positive for exposure to the AIDS virus.
LEAD: WHEN Gino Quilico was 8 years old, he begged his father, the baritone Louis Quilico, not to sing again in ''Don Carlo'' because he hated seeing him shot to death.

LEAD: A Federal inmate who was ordered back to prison after eating poppy seeds against regulations completed his term and was set free today. The inmate, Anthony Clarizio, completed his two-year sentence on loansharking and false-statement charges and was released from the Federal prison in Danbury, a prison spokesman, Lee Enzor, said.
LEAD: Over the opposition of President Reagan, the Senate registered its support today for a proposal requiring adherence to weapons limits in the unratified 1979 treaty limiting strategic arms.

LEAD: The North Carolina Symphony, conducted by Gerhardt Zimmermann, is to perform works by Robert Ward Sunday at 3 P.M. in Carnegie Hall. Soloists include James Houlik, a saxophonist; Victoria Livengood, a mezzo soprano, and Eugene Perry, a baritone. Mr. Ward will conduct the vocal selection. Tickets are $11 to $20.
LEAD: The New York City Board of Estimate unanimously approved a program yesterday to turn over 58 city-owned buildings in the East New York section of Brooklyn to a group of squatters.

LEAD: On Sunday, National Football League games will be played by teams made up of replacements for the striking players, and players who have crossed the picket line. Below is a team-by-team breadkown of players who have returned to work, the number of refunds issued to ticket-holders and the players' plans for activities outside the stadiums.

LEAD: People who fear that the Japanese are taking over the world economy, leaving Americans with nothing left to do but defrost microwave pizzas, are behind the news. Japan's export growth is on the wane, as the high-flying yen makes it ever more difficult for Japanese industry to compete on price.

LEAD: A bipartisan group of 33 members of Congress urged President Reagan today to impose new economic sanctions against South Africa as a means of forcing the Pretoria Government to change its racial policies.
LEAD: Because of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, alternate-side parking will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other rules remain in effect.

LEAD: Despite its pre-eminence as the world's largest retailer of personal computers, the Computerland Corporation has its share of problems, including lengthy litigation, fractious franchisees and declining margins. But to William Y. Tauscher, who took over as chairman last week, the chain, based in Hayward, Calif., seems a good investment.

LEAD: IN spite of the admirable strides made in recent years by many hotel restaurants, diners at large still have a psychological block about frequenting them - images of rubbery surf and turf with foil-wrapped baked potatoes dissipate slowly. Trumpet's, the showcase dining room at the Grand Hyatt on East 42d Street, near Grand Central

LEAD: In the first phase of the personal computer boom, the industry's two software heavyweights - the Microsoft Corporation and the Lotus Development Corporation - thrived largely by staying out of each other's way. That polite, unspoken arrangement ends next week.

LEAD: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Two Soviet long-range missile tests have been protested by the United States, the State Department said. The tests earlier this week sent unarmed warheads into the Pacific Ocean about 600 miles northwest of Hawaii. Page A1 Moscow's intellectual elite gathered last week for an unfettered discussion of hotly disputed issues including censorship and religious persecution.

LEAD: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' all-pro outside linebacker and their highest-paid player, said yesterday he might abandon the strike of National Football League players and report to the team next week. Gary Kovacs, his agent, said Taylor would definitely not play Monday night against the San Francisco 49ers at Giants

LEAD: They Might Be Giants will perform tonight at 9 and midnight, with Watchface opening, at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets (475-5120). Tickets are $10; information, and a sample song, at (718) 387-6962.

LEAD: Like many of the tree-shaded side streets of Manhattan, the section of East 30th Street between Second and Third Avenues still manages to retain some century-old town houses tucked in between the taller, more modern buildings that dominate the streetscape.

LEAD: George Hansen with his wife, Connie, after his release from the Federal prison in Petersburg, Va. Mr. Hansen, who was a Republican Representative from Idaho for seven terms, was convicted in 1984 of violating the Federal Ethics in Government Act for failing to report $330,000 in personal loans and profits on commodities transactions.
LEAD: John A. Zaccaro was depicted yesterday as a ''would-be bagman'' for the late Donald R. Manes who had tried to extort a bribe from a cable television concern seeking a franchise in Queens.
LEAD: The selection of the 12 jurors in the Howard Beach murder trial was completed yesterday as three more Queens residents were chosen to hear the evidence in the racially volatile case.

LEAD: Atlanta completed a triple steal in the fourth inning against the Houston Astros tonight. With Jeff Blauser on first, Ken Oberkfell on second and Gerald Perry on third, the Houston catcher, Ronn Reynolds, threw the ball back to the pitcher, Danny Darwin, just as Perry broke for the plate.

LEAD: The Oakland Athletics' Dave Stewart, who became the first 20-game winner in the major leagues this season when he beat the Cleveland Indians, 4-3, Wednesday night, said yesterday that he deserves the American League Cy Young award but doesn't expect to get it. A castoff pitcher with a losing career record 17 months ago, Stewart has mastered a forkball in posting a 20-12 record.

LEAD: The Moscow Virtuosi, under the conductor and violinist Vladimir Spivakov, is to make its first New York appearance Sunday at 3 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall. The program includes works by Bach, Shostakovich and Tchaikovsky. Tickets are $10 to $20. Information: 874-6770.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, proposing that the Arctic become ''a zone of peace,'' called today for East-West cooperation to reduce military activities and tap natural resources in the area.

LEAD: NYACK, about 25 miles north of New York City, is nestled in a niche of the Palisades that tower over the west bank of the Hudson River. Its location, akin to a cleft in a prominent chin of land, accounts for the village's history and contributes to a variegated present, including a reputation as a mecca for antiques fanciers, a haven for art and theater lovers, and a paradise of

LEAD: A small prototype device has shown that communications lines made from the new generation of superconductors can transmit data at speeds up to 100 times as fast as today's state-of-the-art optical fiber networks, scientists said yesterday.

LEAD: On the day the moratorium on signing draft choices and free agents ended, the National Basketball Association tried to go back to business as usual yesterday. But the players' union took the unusual step of suing the owners.
LEAD: HE looks like a cross between Woody Allen and Sean Penn.
LEAD: If a war of ideas is developing in the Soviet Union, the front line Wednesday evening was at the Oktyabr Theater in Moscow.

LEAD: The Rangers received a shock yesterday morning when they learned that Barry Beck, who was attempting a comeback, reinjured his left shoulder Tuesday night in Denver and almost certainly will not be able to resume his career.

LEAD: IN his show at the David McKee Gallery, William Tucker has in effect turned his sculpture inside out. In the abstract, largely geometrical works that established his reputation, an armature gave shape to a void inside it that eventually became more urgent than the armature itself. Now the bony armature has become a support, and geometrical shapes are fleshed out around it in plaster.

LEAD: The swearing-in ceremony for the new Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, William S. Sessions, was postponed today after Mr. Sessions fainted in the aisle of a Washington-bound jetliner.

LEAD: Clark Terry, a trumpeter, will lead a jazz group tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260). Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M.; there is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and a one-drink minimum at the bar.

LEAD: It's fall in New York and the benefit party circuit is in full swing. Men dressed in black tie and women in their evening regalia are showing up at galas to help the city's many cultural and charitable institutions. Nothing unusual in that. But what's different this season is the age of these revelers-with-a-cause, who are in their late 20's and early 30's.
LEAD: As diplomats posted here are all too aware, it is tough to catch the ear of State Department officials and members of Congress.

LEAD: A NUMBER of hard-to-believe things happen right at the beginning of ''Anna,'' a first film directed by Yurek Bogayevicz and written by Agnieszka (''Angry Harvest'') Holland. No. 1: though the title character, a once-celebrated Czechoslovak actress (played by Sally Kirkland), lives amid the kind of gloomy decor in which one might expect to find an elderly lady, she emerges as a leggy, chic-looking creature.

LEAD: When they look back, the Yankees surely will not want to remember games like the one they played last night at the Stadium. They hit three home runs, stole three bases, owned a four-run lead in the seventh inning and lost.
LEAD: THE Blair String Quartet's recital at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday evening lasted well over two hours but seemed much longer.

LEAD: The second installment in Richard Goode's seven-concert cycle of the complete Beethoven piano sonatas is to be presented Sunday at 3 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The program includes the ''Pathetique'' and ''Les Adieux'' sonatas. Tickets are $12.50. Information: 996-1100.
LEAD: HE Knitting Factory, a club and cafe on 47 East Houston Street, had almost singlehandedly revived New York's downtown arts scene in its first six months of operation.

LEAD: The American Chamber Opera Company is to present a double bill of Peter Westergaard's ''Mr. and Mrs. Discobbolos'' and John Harbison's ''Full Moon in March,'' tonight and tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Marymount Manhattan Theater, at 221 East 71st Street. Tickets are $10, $5 for the elderly and students. Information: 781-0857.
LEAD: The PTL ministry has filed a bankruptcy reorganization plan that would divide the evangelical empire into profit-seeking and nonprofit entities.

LEAD: Jack the Ripper, the Victorian murderer who terrorized London 99 years ago and was never caught, was a failed barrister and schoolmaster named Montague John Druitt, two writers say in a book published today.

LEAD: A severe earthquake shook the Los Angeles area today, tearing glass from skyscrapers, jolting cars on freeways, killing at least 6 people and injuring more than 100 in a half minute of violent tremors.

LEAD: WITHOUT being polemical, the current exhibition at the Pat Hearn Gallery proposes some loose and interesting connections among the work of five artists who happen to be women. LEAD: UNLIKE the girl in ''A Chorus Line'' who was told she'd be very attractive when she grew up, ''different, with a special something,'' Sheila McCarthy doesn't believe that pretty is necessarily what it's about.

LEAD: When the earthquake struck, Edward Fontaine was perched precariously 300 feet above downtown Los Angeles. Sitting in the control cabin of a construction crane atop the framework of a new 26-story office building, he was thrown violently to one side as the crane began swaying ominously.

LEAD: A sampling of women's attitudes on their relationships with men by an author of best-selling books on sexuality has found that 84 percent of women queried were ''not satisfied emotionally'' with their marriages or romantic involvements.

LEAD: The signs do not bode well for the Toronto Blue Jays, even though they are in first place by a game in the American League East heading into their decisive three-game series against the Tigers in Detroit beginning tonight.

LEAD: The United States and its major North Atlantic allies have reportedly joined in backing a West German to become NATO's next Secretary General, according to diplomats and Government officials here.

LEAD: Efforts by the House Ways and Means Committee to begin drafting a tax bill today were scuttled after Republicans disputed the need to raise $12 billion from new taxes and refused to consider any specific revenue-raising proposals.

LEAD: The shares of the National Semiconductor Corporation rose sharply after Federal regulators cleared the way for its acquisition of the Fairchild Semiconductor Corporation. The stock gained $1.875 a share, to $20.25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

LEAD: IF all those movies about black-white teams of hero-adventurers strike you as kid stuff, you haven't seen anything yet. ''Big Shots,'' which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, is kid stuff with kids.

LEAD: The Southland Corporation said it would receive $52 million in cash from the sale of its Movie Quik movie-rental division and $80 million for 270 of its 7-Eleven stores in the Houston area. LEAD: Sada Thompson as a Saleswoman
LEAD: The world should be holding its breath, hoping that the leaders of the United States and Soviet Union will have the vision and guts to bring about a new era in superpower relations.

LEAD: As if the loss of the Senate, the Iran-contra affair, the troubled Robert Bork nomination and a lame-duck status were not demoralizing enough, the Reagan Administration must now try to plug an inevitable, but nonetheless debilitating, end-of-term loss of personnel.
LEAD: A rebound in apartment building helped spur construction spending, which rose 1.6 percent in August, the biggest increase in four months, the Government said today.

LEAD: Responding to a defiant declaration by a Fijian coup leader that he had taken charge, Queen Elizabeth II declared today that she continued to regard the island nation's Governor General as the sole legitimate authority.
LEAD: ALL the papers were signed yesterday, $650 million changed hands and the CBS Magazine division became Diamandis Communications Inc.

LEAD: The attorney for John A. Zaccaro filed a letter with a State Supreme Court justice yesterday that contains information about his client's past that he says should not be introduced by the prosecution in Mr. Zaccaro's extortion trial.

LEAD: Gleaming stainless-steel subway cars will have their debut today on the 42d Street shuttle, the latest attempt to spruce up a nearly 70-year-old line that opened to bad reviews and has mostly been getting them since.

LEAD: President Reagan rejected additional economic sanctions against South Africa today, prompting sharp criticism from some members of Congress and promises of tougher measures against the white minority Government.

LEAD: The Weekender Guide report about ''The Mahabharata,'' by the Theater of Understanding, misstated performance dates. The production runs through Nov. 1 at the American Theater of Actors, 314 West 54th Street.

LEAD: Because of Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. Other rules remain in effect.
LEAD: An investor group dominated by the Ford Motor Company signed an agreement yesterday to buy the Hertz Corporation, the nation's largest car-rental company, from the Allegis Corporation.

LEAD: All season, Tommy John has defied the popular belief that he was either too old or too fragile to pitch effectively for the Yankees. Last night at the Stadium, he proved it again.

LEAD: Fay Koshelle, a founder with her husband of a children's camp in the Catskills, died Wednesday at the Hebrew Home of Greater Washington in Rockville, Md., where she was a resident. She was 102 years old. Mrs. Koshelle, a onetime Bronx resident, and her husband, the late William Koshelle, founded the Maple Lake Camp in Livingston Manor, N.Y., in 1925, and operated it for more than 30 years.

LEAD: The principal stockholder in the Central National Bank of New York was charged yesterday with defrauding the bank, which was declared insolvent and closed last month, of $31.4 million from customers' accounts, the United States Attorney's office in Manhattan said.

LEAD: Walter Murray, the Indianapolis Colts wide receiver who first joined the National Football League players' strike, then rejoined the Colts, then returned to the pickets, was back in the team's uniform today.

LEAD: Rito Ocbian, his wife and their seven children gathered their meager belongings, including a squealing hog and three chickens, packed them in jute sacks and loaded them on a bamboo sled drawn by their water buffalo.

LEAD: The show opened with a zebra-striped calfskin coat rimmed in silver fox. After a few suits with fitted jackets, flaring peplums and ostentatious puffed-sleeve blouses, the key to Arnold Scaasi's fall couture collection appeared. LEAD: Rosa von Praunheim's ''Anita -Dances of Vice'' is a surprisingly tame movie to be made by the German director responsible for ''It's Not the Homosexual Who Is Perverse, Rather the Situation in Which He Lives'' (1970) and ''A Virus Knows No Morals'' (made in 1985 and released here this year). The former is a memorably savage satire on gay liberation conformism, while the latter is a grim examination of what might be called gay liberation's aftermath, in the era of acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

LEAD: LEOPARD spots are certainly leaving their mark on New York. The distinctive buff and black rosette patterns, which occur naturally on leopards, are now being reproduced artificially on all sorts of things. They're woven into wool and chiffon, stenciled onto leather and calfskin, and even dyed on the top of closely shorn heads (that hairdo should be interesting as it grows out).
LEAD: Curry college has been struck by an outbreak of viral meningitis that has afflicted 21 students in the past two weeks.

LEAD: At least three dozen men are slumped or sleeping in molded plastic chairs in the center for the homeless. It is 8 P.M., and they are waiting to be assigned beds for the night. Several say they have been waiting all day.

LEAD: THE state's deer population, which is on the rise, is providing thrilling sights for nature lovers. It is also causing annoyance to gardeners, economic problems for farmers and severe danger to motorists, particularly Fairfield County motorists.

LEAD: NEW Jerseyans have known for some time that they pay the highest auto insurance premiums in the country. But as the cost continues to rise, while neighboring states seem able to restrain increases, the high price of coverage is emerging as an important political issue.
LEAD: Tyrone Thurman, who is only 5 feet 3 inches and 130 pounds, returned a punt 74 yards for a touchdown to launch Texas Tech to a 27-21 Southwest Conference upset of Texas A&M today.

LEAD: After weeks of debate over the Reagan Administration's Central America policy, the White House has settled on a list of demands it says the Nicaraguan Government must accept if the Sandinistas hope to forestall a request to Congress for renewed military aid to the contras.

LEAD: THE PAPERBACK OF E. M. Forster's ''Maurice'' that has been brought out to coincide with the film of the novel bears a time-honored slogan on its cover: ''Now a Major Motion Picture.'' I don't think such a claim would have appealed much to Forster himself, who always made rather a point of not being a major anything; and since ''Maurice'' is by common consent the least successful of his novels, even his warmest admirers are likely to quail at the thought of a movie inflating the book beyond its proper dimensions.

LEAD: IT is a common enough occurrence for news as it grows old to turn into history but in my experience it is rare for history as it grows old to turn into news. Rare or not, something of the kind appears to have happened with respect to ''Here at The New Yorker,'' which, having been published back in 1975, may be said to have passed into history, but which has lately become news on the strength of the many changes that have been taking place at the magazine over the last couple of years.

LEAD: The death of Henry Ford 2d at the age of 70 is not expected to affect the management of the big auto maker, but it will leave a void in the corporate culture. A man who believed the boss should be the boss, Mr. Ford nevertheless was not one to dismiss counsel lightly; indeed, when he seized control of the company in 1945, he listened carefully to those who knew more about running it than he did, until he had a firm grasp of its operations.

LEAD: Kashmir is an emerald set in a ring of Himalayan mountains. At its current price in the United States, one ounce of saffron is literally worth its weight in gold.

LEAD: ALL the signs point to an American victory in the world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl due to begin in a week's time in Ocho Rios, Jamaica. The United States has the same experienced squad that won two years ago in Sao Paulo, Brazil: Bob Wolff and Bob Hamman of Dallas, and four California players, Chip Martel of Davis, Lew Stansby of Castro Valley, Hugh Ross of Oakland, and Peter Pender of San Francisco.

LEAD: HIGHWAYS and country roadsides boast plumes of wild flowers, seed pods and grasses that might be clipped and gathered in bunches to hang dry upside down. They can be used later in floral arrangements for the house during winter. Keep up with harvest from the vegetable and fruit gardens. Finish digging, dividing and replanting the early-blooming perennials.

LEAD: Monsignor Farrell of Staten Island, last season's Catholic High Schools Football League champion, won its second game of this season in much the same way it won all the games on its schedule last year. The Lions were led by their fine quarterback, Gary Wilkos, over Holy Cross, 30-6.

LEAD: Victor Mollo, one of the world's leading writers on contract bridge, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in London. He was 78 years old.

LEAD: POLITICS, Will Rogers commented in the 1930's, ''has got so expensive it takes a lot of money even to get beat with.'' The Rogers observation is even more accurate in the 1980's. LEAD: THE Lehman College Art Gallery's present attraction is a group of small sculptures, pottery and textiles. Most are pre-Columbian, the rest are African or Melanesian and all were drawn from the college's Testut-Obstfield Collection. On view through Oct. 24, it is a show with no title and precious little documentation and, confined to the smaller of the gallery's two spaces, it could easily be overlooked.

LEAD: AN ENCHANTED EVENING IN ROME DEPENDS on convivial company and good food and drink. As in France, eating out here tends to be a religious ritual, but generally it's low church rather than high, and occasionally closer to a fundamentalist revival than to a solemn benediction. There is no hush of holy sacrament, no delicate gourmet sipping and pecking.

LEAD: EVERY once in a while, President Reagan's aides suggest that, on a particular controversy, it would be best if he just kept quiet. That was the view for months in the heat of the Iran-contra affair. Once, the President even pleaded laryngitis to avoid answering reporters' questions.

LEAD: When did it consciously begin, this delight in decayed or wrecked buildings? Very early, it seems. Since down the ages men have meditated before ruins, rhapsodized before them, mourned pleasurably over their ruination, it is interesting to speculate on the various strands in this complex enjoyment, on how much of it is admiration for the ruin as it was in its prime .

LEAD: In a courtyard near El Prado, the main thoroughfare of La Paz, Bolivia, Isabel Mamani kneels on the floor as she grinds cochineal on a stone mortar, the kind of mortar used in most Bolivian homes to grind hot pepper, garlic and spices. Cochineal, an insect that feeds on cactus, is also the name of a dye produced from female cochineal; a spectrum of reds, from scarlet to rust, is the result, and the colors are used to dye a line of scarves, sweaters and shawls produced by Artesanias Millma.
LEAD: Barring a last-minute hitch, President Jose Napoleon Duarte and leaders of the guerrilla front fighting his Government are to meet here Sunday for the first time formally in nearly three years.

LEAD: A man stopped for suspected drunken driving led the police on a high-speed chase, hurt a deputy with a rock, and was wounded several hours later by a state trooper after aiming a shotgun at officers, the police said.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Washington dispatch last Sunday about Bob Woodward's new book on the Central Intelligence Agency erroneously suggested the sequence of reports on indirect American links to a car bombing in Lebanon in March 1985. The Washington Post first disclosed the links on May 12, 1985; The New York Times's reporting, which appeared the next day, confirmed that of The Post.

LEAD: HOW WONDERFUL TO SEE RAINY STREETS once more, wrote the Goncourt brothers in their joint diary after a stay in intolerably sunny Rome. Since giving up painting for photography more than a decade ago, he has progressed from an early fascination with the medium's ability to describe surfaces to a sophisticated understanding of the ways in which chance and ambiguity shape the meaning of images.

Some years ago there was the temptation to add a few dollars to the city's coffers by permitting the construction of an underground garage beneath the park, and one can only be grateful for hesitation there.

LEAD: EVERY year when sunlight returns to the Antarctic, scientists can chart a thinning patch in the earth's ozone sunscreen. Every year the measurements are more precise and more ominous, and this year they were worse than ever.

LEAD: ROGER CRAIG emerged from the tunnel connecting the locker room and the dugout. He was wearing a heavy San Francisco Giants windbreaker that concealed his uniform shirt, a synthetic warm-up, a cotton sweatshirt and a T-shirt. As he watched batting practice under a gray, misty sky, his right hand gripped a paper cup filled with coffee, steam escaping as if from a smokestack.

LEAD: THE hackers who break into a company's computers are usually on the intellectual equivalent of joyrides. Using their home computers and modems, they prowl the electronic avenues searching for an unlocked computer with the ''key in the ignition'' - one with an easily defeated security system. Once inside, they take the computer for a spin.
LEAD: ONE of the first omens that Donald Kagan was going to take some strange turns in life manifested itself at the age of 9 while he was growing up in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, N.Y.

LEAD: THE RECENT REOPENING OF the Mauritshuis in The Hague after a five-year closure is an event of international importance. LEAD: THE Treasury Secretary, James A. Baker 3d, derides those who would belittle the President's capacity to pull any more rabbits from his hat, at least on matters of economics. Making his point in just five days, Mr. Baker, whose own innovative image had seemed to be fading along with Mr. Reagan's, has dramatically transformed the look of economic policy.

LEAD: IN the life of a book, a book fair is perhaps the final chapter. Removed, perhaps still unread, from the dusty shelf on which it has spent most of its existence, the book joins many of its kind on a table where, under usually chaotic conditions, it is inspected and most likely sold at a fraction of its original retail value.

LEAD: AS a child I lived with my parents in a small modern apartment in a remote suburb of Paris. My father's study, with its single window overlooking well-tended vegetable gardens, was a sunny, quiet room, walled with books and journals. The thin, light-colored ones were collections of contemporary poetry in French and Russian.

LEAD: DENVILLE FESTIVAL The Morris County community of Denville annually attracts more than 50,000 visitors to its Harvest Festival, which this year will be held Saturday. LEAD: EUROPEAN hotel dining rooms have long been meccas for marvelous food. In the last few years, American hotels have begun to blossom with highly rated restaurants. Restaurant Giorgio in the Garden City Hotel is in this new sumptuous mode.

LEAD: ''THE DEADLY GAME,'' now at the Arena Players, is an adaptation by James Yaffe of a Friedrich Duerrenmatt's novel. The play is a thriller that milks its chills not from dramatic action, but rather from the subtle interplay of warped intellects. It is a drama that demands its audience pay attention to every word, because the tension builds with the slow, steady, intricate movement of a courtroom drama.

LEAD: Golf Scotland vs. England: Scotland beat the United States, 3-0, and England upset the two-time defending champion, Australia, 2-1, yesterday in the semifinals of the Dunhill Cup team tournament in St. Andrew's, Scotland. Nick Faldo, the British Open champion, sank a 15-foot birdie putt on the final hole to clinch England's place in the final after Rodger Davis of Australia, who had shot a course-record 63 Friday, squandered a three-stroke lead over the final three holes.

LEAD: LAST year, Sir Freddie Laker traveled to Ayers Rock, a remote spot in Australia's midlands that is considered the best location from which to view Halley's Comet. He had completed the 4,800-foot climb to the peak, he recalls, when a woman came up to him and said, ''You're Freddie Laker.''

LEAD: TO PARAPHRASE GEORGE BER-nard Shaw, I have been to the Metropolitan Opera three times in a week and I still live. To open the 1987-88 season, the company offered ''Otello'' as an hors d'oeuvre for Verdi lovers, then lured us to Massenet's ''Manon'' and Strauss's ''Ariadne auf Naxos.'' Only the ''Ariadne,'' though vocally uneven and often downright frustrating, stays brightly in mind, which might seem odd.

My husband resorted to selective deafness, until, suddenly a week later, he jumped up from his desk chair and appropos of nothing, asked, ''Well, are we buying a new car or what?

LEAD: I DON'T USUALLY HUNT FOR ROMANTIC PLACES to dine. I take my chances. I let each place possess me in its own way, and wait for surfacings of special delight and poignance that will cause me to return.

LEAD: The centerpiece of the operatic week is Friday night's opening of ''Das Rheingold'' at the Met. This is the least outwardly exciting of the four operas that make up Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle, and it hardly ever sells out, so there is a good chance for late deciders to hear it, either this time or at one of the repetitions.

LEAD: It used to be called the Paris of the Balkans, and it is still possible to see why, at least in part: the broad, tree-lined avenues and the buildings designed by French Beaux-Arts architects make Bucharest one of the handsomest cities in Eastern Europe. But the animation, the excitement and, of course, the showy upper class are long gone.

LEAD: THERE ARE IN BRITAIN VANISHED cities, lost villages, disappeared kingdoms even, some with their names still on the map. Trying to reach them isn't quite as hopeless as trying to reach the rainbow's end, but the point at which their legend and their geography meet is sure to be buried in a thicket of poetry.

LEAD: RAVENNA IS A PLEASANT NORTHERN ITALIAN TOWN practically on the Adriatic coast. The city and its surroundings are flat, which makes for easy walking and accounts for the city's bicycle cult. Bicycles are parked thickly, leaving the streets comparatively free of standing cars.

LEAD: SPRING is the best time to inspect chimneys and fireplaces. The heating season is over, acids formed by combustion residues have not yet had a chance to corrode chimney parts seriously and plenty of time is available for repairs before cold weather sets in again.

The Soviet violinist and conductor is here from Moscow with the chamber orchestra he formed eight years ago, the Moscow Virtuosi.

LEAD: THREE offbeat programs with an international flavor highlight the week's concert schedule, beginning today at 3 P.M. when the fine young clarinetist (and Yonkers resident) Esther Lamneck plays a free recital at the White Plains Library that includes a piece for a Hungarian relative of the clarinet called the tarogato.

LEAD: Autumn in Jerusalem is a season of deep and generous pause in the ritual and agricultural life of this holy city. Now the sun, the color of old burnished gold, hangs steady in the sky before beginning its slide into winter's silver depths. Soon the sapphire-blue skies of the waning dry season, as if in response to autumnal prayers rising from synagogues the world over, will give way to mists, heralds of winter rains to soak the new-laid seeds and bring on the crops of spring.

LEAD: America pioneered in photographing the earth from space, but its pictures for civilian use are now third best, behind those of France and the Soviet Union. The Russians take the most precise photos.

LEAD: ACCEPTANCE of short skirts has been abetted to a large extent by the fact that in the beginning - last spring - they were almost always presented with opaque panty hose, usually black. Many women switched in summer to sheerer stockings. These continue to be important with short evening dresses, but another category of panty hose is coming to the fore as cool weather approaches: a heavier style that can provide some warmth.
