LEAD: A REPORT commissioned by the state's Department of Health at the request of residents here contends that the presence of thorium has not increased the incidence of cancer.

LEAD: ''THEY'RE ALLOPREENING,'' says Donald J. Sterner, hopefully, of the two California condors shown above. The endangered birds are circumspect breeders, a problem for Sterner, whose job it is, as lead condor keeper at the San Diego Wild Animal Park, to assist the perpetuation of the species. Allopreening, a ritual that frequently precedes the male's formal courtship of the female, consists of ''bits of behavior that bring them closer, nibbling each others' feathers, head and neck rubbing,'' Sterner says.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: To the Sports Editor:
LEAD: JAZZ MUSICIANS IMPRO-vise, but is improvisation what defines their music as jazz?

LEAD: A bipartisan group of 40 prominent Americans, including advisers to several presidential candidates, has expressed concern that the United States and other Western countries are failing ''to respond creatively to the opportunities offered by the new directions in Soviet policy.''

LEAD: TWENTY YEARS AGO, THE BEST LONDON RES-taurants - and there weren't many of them - specialized in a kind of Edwardian-French cuisine: strong tastes, lavish portions and an emphasis on creatures that can be shot - in other words, classic cooking for the hungry squirearchy. Then nouvelle cuisine arrived to decimate the portions, overrefine the flavors and generally ruin our fun in the name of preserving our waistlines.

LEAD: A TROLLEY-CAR parade, a re-enactment of a comic strip about trolleys and, of course, trolley rides highlight next weekend as the Shore Line Trolley Museum kicks off a yearlong celebration marking the 100th anniversary of trolleys.
LEAD: Greg Bohannon rushed for 116 yards today to lead Bowdoin to a 29-7 victory over Amherst.

LEAD: When the history of suburban real estate development is written, Springhurst Park in Dobb's Ferry, N.Y., could be footnoted as having risen from one of the longest-running approvals struggles ever. It began in 1960, when the late Edward C. Iannace, a Westchester County developer, started seeking cluster zoning for his own eight-acre lot, which supported the family mansion - a nine-bedroom, 7,000-square-foot colonial.
LEAD: Hundreds of police officers seeking to stop terrorist operations by Basque separatists based in France arrested 68 people today, officials said.

LEAD: SCANDINAVIAN SYMPHONIES, excepting those of Sibelius, have not become staple items on orchestral programs outside that geographical area, although some have long been available on recordings. Setting aside value judgments on the works themselves, there are two likely reasons for this neglect: the relatively primitive nature of Scandinavian musical life in the early part of the 19th century, and the (continuing) peripheral location of the

LEAD: ON Columbus Avenue near 61st Street, a young man sits beside a bridge table stacked with copies of what a poster describes as ''an original novel.'' The slender volumes, which he has apparently published himself, are attractively priced at $2. The young man is handsome, not visibly eccentric. He regards me with an open, frank expression - an unusual attitude for a novelist.
LEAD: LIVING WITH CHRONIC ILLNESS Days of Patience and Passion. By Cheri Register. 316 pp. New York: The Free Press. $19.95.

LEAD: United States and Canadian trade negotiators, racing against a midnight deadline, narrowed differences today on a trade pact that would eliminate tariffs and other barriers between the world's two largest trading partners, according to officials familiar with the talks.

LEAD: CAFE NEVO. By Barbara Rogan. (Atheneum, $19.95.) The Cafe Nevo is a seedy, dusty Tel Aviv bistro that operates as a stage for the handful of querulous artistic souls who regularly collect there to concoct literary schemes, flaunt extramarital liaisons and achieve respite from the omnipresent reality of the war in Lebanon as well as the past sorrows of the flight from Germany that carried many to the Middle East.

LEAD: THE New York Rangers goalie, John Vanbiesbrouck, suffered a broken jaw during a practice session yesterday, but is expected to miss only a game or two of the regular season. . . . At the age of 38, Steve Garvey may be playing his final major-league game today. The first baseman's contract with the San Diego Padres expires after the game, the last of the season, and the club's president, Chub Feeney, said it would not be renewed.

LEAD: An article on Sept. 20 about greeting cards incorrectly described the relationship between the American Greetings Corporation and Rousana Cards. American Greetings bought certain distribution rights and inventories from Rousana, which remains an independent company.
LEAD: MOST VIENNESE ARE MYTH makers - as am I, even though I'm a Mets-rooting Upper West Sider. I was born in Vienna, and am thus naturally inclined to mythopoeia, sometimes by sheer accident.

LEAD: WHEN Kim and William Madden sold their Danbury house this year and moved to a new three-bedroom, $130,000 home in Naugatuck, their families and friends were apprehensive. ''They told us that Naugatuck is next to Waterbury - that it's a bad area,'' Mrs. Madden said. ''We love it.''

LEAD: SOME people not only follow the beat of a different drummer, but create different drums -and other instruments - as well. They make hand-crafted musical instruments that range from wooden drums played for relaxation to classical Turkish lutes used by musical scholars.

LEAD: ON Oct. 16, the seventh annual observance of the United Nations-sponsored World Food Day takes place. Its purpose: to draw attention to the issue of hunger. In the United States there is a growing number of people dedicating themselves to one partial solution to this problem at home. They call themselves food bankers.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Reid Cheswick of Darien, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carol Ann Cheswick to Richard Thomas Ross, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Ross Jr., also of Darien. The couple plan to be married Nov. 21.

LEAD: Margaret Grace Farrell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Farrell of Oakdale, L.I., and New Smyrna Beach, Fla., and Vincent Pluvinage, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Pierre Pluvinage of Brussels, were married yesterday. Msgr. John T. Fagan performed the ceremony in the Lady Chapel at St. Patrick's Cathedral in New

LEAD: Woody Herman was in critical condition today at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, a hospital spokesman said. The 74-year-old band leader was on a life-support system in the intensive care unit, the spokesman, Ron Wise said. Mr. Herman was hospitalized Thursday because of congestive heart failure, emphysema and pneumonia, said his attorney, Kirk Pasich.

LEAD: To win the International Motor Sports Association's 1987 Camel GT sports car driving title, all Chip Robinson needs to do at today's Columbus Ford Dealer's 500 is to stay close behind Price Cobb.
LEAD: With pomp and flourish, The International Herald Tribune, an American newspaper abroad, celebrated its 100th anniversary in Paris this week.

LEAD: IF the first generation of food bankers in the mid to late 70's brought a personal commitment to feeding the hungry, the second generation has combined that commitment with a heavy overlay of professionalism.

LEAD: THE MARKINGS ON THE WOODEN packing case were deceptive. ''Horlick's Malted Milk Tablets,'' they said. And the box was long thought to contain supplies for Roald Amundsen, the Norwegian explorer who not only discovered the South Pole but also was the first to fly across the Arctic. When the box was turned over to the organizers of an Amundsen exhibition last year by the widow of the explorer's nephew and heir, it was found to hold not supplies but something much rarer: more than 200 lantern slides of

LEAD: Richard Gene Brinkman of Wilton, Conn., and Jensen Beach,. Fla., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Lisa Benson Brinkman, to Michael Charles Jensen Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jensen of New York and Peekskill, N.Y. A November wedding is planned.
LEAD: In his essay ''Bottom-Line Days'' (Sunday Observer, Sept. 6), Russell Baker bemoans a current lack of passion in reference to Labor Day and other mores of our society.

LEAD: Weeks This Last On Week Fiction Week List 1 PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow. 1 15 (Farrar, Straus & Girous, $18.95.) A brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and lawyers. 2 PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, 2 10 $19.95.) The C.I.A.
LEAD: IS there theater life in East Hampton after the summer folks have gone? Kelly Patton, the artistic director for public programs at the John Drew Theater, is all set to prove there is.

LEAD: BEFORE THE DAY'S RE-hearsal of ''Dancin','' his 1978 Broadway show, Bob Fosse stopped to answer a few questions, but his mind was not on conversation; his feet wanted to work. Then he put on a pair of white gloves and faced his dancers, all of whom were wearing identical white gloves and straw hats at a rakish Fosse tilt (over one eye, as if to ward off the glare of artificial light).

LEAD: In Margarita Nylen's view of yacht racing, age is on her side. The 32-year-old sailor from Stockholm and four of her Swedish teammates are in Newport, R.I., this week to compete in the Rolex International Women's Keelboat Championship.

LEAD: IS ''Near Dark'' a mainstream commercial movie, tinged with blood, about an Oklahoma farm boy seduced and abducted by vampires? Or is it a fast-money thriller with artsy photography, about rowdy bloodsuckers who live like bikers and drive by night?

LEAD: FROM ROCKAWAY. By Jill Eisenstadt. (Knopf, $15.95.) The misadventures of a group of going-nowhere teen-agers in Jill Eisenstadt's first novel, ''From Rockaway,'' would seem to confirm every parent's worst nightmares about what his or her children do when left to their own devices. The book's central characters are a handful of college-age (though not necessarily college-bound) kids, for whom the tedium of their small, dreary world is relieved only by self-destructive rebellion and atavistic ritual.

LEAD: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Riccobene of Franklin Lakes, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Maura Anne Riccobene to Jonathan Brereton Bulkeley, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Bulkeley of Bloomfield and Old Saybrook, Conn. The couple plan to marry Dec. 20. Ms. Riccobene, an account manager for U.S.

LEAD: The Greek police said today that they had raided hide-outs of a left-wing terrorist group that took responsibility for a bomb attack on an American military post exchange store here six days ago.

LEAD: Raymond S. Dinsmore, a real-estate developer and world traveler who, in the late 1950's, was president of the Circumnavigators Club, an organization of travelers who have circled the globe, died Monday at the John F. Kennedy Memorial Hospital in Atlantis, Fla., of complications from a stroke. He was 87 years old and a resident of Manhattan.
LEAD: LEAVING HOME By Garrison Keillor. 244 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

LEAD: The final days have not been easy ones. Sometimes it seemed as if they were moving at an annoying pace, as if someone had slowed them to half-speed. Players were spent; the manager appeared worn.

LEAD: As expected, Columbia tied a record it doesn't want or need, losing yesterday to Penn, 23-0, despite some early moments of hope for their followers. The defeat was the Lions' 34th in a row, which equals the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I record set by Northwestern from 1979-82.

LEAD: To the Editor: For a half-day outing in Madrid appealing to sightseers and art lovers alike, I recommend a visit to the Spanish Museum of Contemporary Art followed by a walk in West Park. The museum is on Avenida Juan de Herrera in University City in the northwest sector of Madrid (not on the Paseo de Recoletos as reported in ''What's Doing in Madrid,'' July 5).

LEAD: Sender Rahmani, a Westchester real-estate developer, died of lung cancer Tuesday at the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 87 years old and a resident of White Plains.
LEAD: Sometimes, when taking off or landing at Barajas Airport here, American fighter planes from Torrejon Air Base can be spotted in the distance on training missions.

LEAD: MOST OF WHAT IS known about ancient Eskimo art has been discovered over the last 60 years. And the vast majority of the evocative, highly sophisticated works, carved between 300 B.C. and A.D. 1200, assembled in ''Ancient Eskimo Ivories of the Bering Strait,'' opening Friday at the Museum of Natural History, were excavated more recently - since about 1970.

LEAD: IF YOU LIVE IN NEW ORLEANS, EXPECT guests. My family and I moved here in 1985. The guests came and there was never any problem entertaining them. The city took care of that. Though economically battered, New Orleans is still one of the world's great party towns - the result of a languorous climate, an abundance of food, especially from the sea, and a confluence of tolerant, somewhat exotic cultures on their unworried way to decadence.
LEAD: IN MY FAMILY, SUCCESS IS WEIGHED BY A single standard: The ability to be first. It does not matter what you are first at as long as you are first at something.
LEAD: IF Ivan Lendel commuted from Greenwich to the U.S. Open, I wonder whether he used Metro-North. I've never seen him on the platform and I'm sure I'd notice someone carrying five tennis rackets.
LEAD: JAMES MADISON The Founding Father. By Robert Allen Rutland. 287 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Company. $19.95.

LEAD: Three fine films on cable this week are interesting examples of novels lifted from the page to celluloid. In its television debut, E. M. Forster's ''Room With a View'' (1986) arrives on Sunday at 8 P.M. on Showtime, repeating on Thursday at 11:30 P.M. The rarely shown thriller made from John Le Carre's ''Spy Who Came in From the Cold'' (1966) reappears on Sunday at noon and Thursday at 4 P.M.

LEAD: Guilford, Conn. $209,000 20 Barnshed Lane 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 7-year-old contemporary; private tree-covered lot, cathedral ceilings, eat-in kitchen, 1.4 acres; taxes $2,088. Killingworth, Conn. $228,500 26 Lovers Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 15-year-old colonial; huge closet space, private setting, 2.5 acres; taxes $2,640.

LEAD: Chief Warrant Officer Charles B. Russell, the last marine on active duty to serve in World War II, retired Friday. The 62-year-old marine, who survived two South Pacific battles in World War II but was seriously wounded in the Vietnam War, was given the Marine Corps's meritorious service medal at his retirement ceremony.

LEAD: Steve Walsh passed for three touchdowns in the final 16 minutes today, including a 73-yard play to Michael Irvin with 2 minutes 22 seconds left, that rallied Miami to a stunning 26-25 victory over Florida State.
LEAD: ALL-YOU-CAN-EAT buffets conjure up visions of drab motel dining rooms crowded with hungry bargain hunters. The Garden City Hotel's seafood buffet shatters this stereotype.
LEAD: INSIDE THE PHILIPPINE REVOLUTION By William Chapman. 288 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $18.95.

LEAD: ELENA SOFONOVA DOES IT ALL with her eyes. She suffers with them, smiles with them, searches with them - now for love, now simply for self-respect. Soft and deep-set above the high Slavic cheekbones, they seem by far the strongest of her tools as an actress. For her last two films, first the 1985 Soviet film ''Winter Cherries'' and now the widely admired Italian-Soviet offering, ''Dark Eyes,'' they have given her a way to evoke eloquently and almost silently the emotions of a charming and charmable woman who wants something more out of life than charm.
LEAD: For the past 35 years, Cole Farms, a restaurant in Gray, about 15 miles north of here, has been open every day except Thanksgiving and Christmas.

LEAD: BECAUSE it is being waged in the District of Columbia, both sides say there is more than usual at stake in the latest battle over whether to require a deposit on bottles and cans: If the District's voters say yes to Initiative 28 on Nov. 3, other states may be encouraged to go forward with similar measures.

LEAD: Washington has reached rock bottom in its five-year search for an underground site to store spent fuel from nuclear reactors. The latest scheme, devised by Senator Bennett Johnston of Louisiana, would make Nevada the unlucky host, recompensed with a $5 billion bribe. Congress's other ideas being even worse, this one deserves attention.

LEAD: Dr. Fred J. Benjamin, a general practitioner and radiologist who practiced in Brooklyn and Manhattan and was the host in recent years of a radio program on health, died of a heart attack on Sept. 26 at New York Hospital. He was 48 years old and lived in Manhattan.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: Matt Less, the Columbia quarterback, being sacked by Penn's Bill Lista. The Lions lost, 23-0, for their 34th straight defeat. Page 5. (NYT/Keith Meyers)

LEAD: AS ALWAYS, TELE-vised hearings churn up new uses of old terms. As the Senate deliberated the nomination to the Supreme Court of Judge Robert H. Bork, logophiles weighed the words of the solons and the nominee.

LEAD: WHEN government operates on the level of rhetoric, it is often surprisingly easy to achieve consensus. When, however, it must move from rhetoric to specific policy recommendations, that consensus can evaporate quickly. Often, the discrete meaning of rhetorical principles depends upon one's perspective.
LEAD: A CANNIBAL IN MANHATTAN By Tama Janowitz. Illustrated by Tony Wright. 287 pp. New York: Crown Publishers. $17.95.

LEAD: To 66 artists, writers, entertainers and other people who had ''at one time or another during my life been very kind to me,'' Bob Fosse, the choreographer and director who died last month, has left $25,000 ''to go out and have dinner on me.''
LEAD: Tamil separatists continued a rampage against majority Sinhalese residents today in attacks that have left more than 2,500 homeless in the last three days.
LEAD: To the Editor: Much as I liked Paul Hofmann's article on Viennese streetcars (Travel, Aug. 23), two additional features need mentioning:
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: WHEN Route 18 was widened to four lanes nearly 30 years ago, this part of Middlesex County was relatively undeveloped and the highway functioned largely as a local road.

LEAD: IT USED to be that everyone understood what was meant by realism; however, for much of the 20th century, the term has been in doubt. After all, the new realism that raged in Germany in the 1920's is not to be confused with the new realism that was Pop or, for that matter, with metaphysical, magical or romantic realism.
LEAD: THE K.G.B. IS WOR-ried about its image.

LEAD: NOT so sensible or cheering, in selection or in execution, is the WPI Theater's first production this season, the pseudomusical, ''Quilters.'' Here is a case of a small theater company overextended.

LEAD: I am a 31-year-old woman who has lived with multiple sclerosis for six years, and I know some who have lived with it for 20. I read with dismay Rand V. Araskog's article ''Award of Honor'' (About Men, Sept. 6). Its depiction of MS was confusing and misleading. MS is a neurological illness that varies considerably from person to person, and even within the same person.
LEAD: It won't be the greatest show on earth, but a display headed for Yale University will offer a sampling of P.T. Barnum's famous circus.
LEAD: To the Editor: Marian Burros's ''Living in Luxury in Bangkok'' (Travel, July 19) brought to mind my experiences at the Oriental Hotel and the Sheraton Royal Orchid.
LEAD: I would gladly attend one of the sub games that the N.F.L. proposes on the condition that I receive live television coverage of my Sunday night poker game.

LEAD: IN HIS LOFT IN A WORKING-CLASS SECTION OF Paris, Peter Brook, the British theater director famous for his ''Marat-Sade,'' ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' and his more recent, controversial ''La Tragedie de Carmen,'' sits at a white enamel table in his kitchen drinking Perrier water. Photographs of his wife, the actress Natasha Parry, and their two children, Irina and Simon, now in their 20's and pursuing film careers, hang on the whitewashed walls.

LEAD: AFTER 12 days of negotiations, demonstrations, accusations, union meetings, owner meetings, sponsor pullouts, picket lines, egg-throwing, name-calling, team-restocking and growing public dissatisfaction with the football industry in general, the National Football League returns to action today. Sort of.

LEAD: Because most tourists in Burma spend only a day or two in Rangoon - a byproduct of the seven-day limit on visas - many don't venture beyond the hotels for meals. Most hotel dining rooms are not distinguished by either the atmosphere or the food.

LEAD: Q. In the basement of our 80-year-old house the pipes are covered with asbestos and in some places the asbestos is cracking and flaking. We do not use this basement for anything except storage and doing the laundry, but we are still concerned. Should we have this repaired, and if so, by whom?

LEAD: Alexia Aisha Larr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Larr of Rye, N.Y., and Richard Walker Duker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Duker Jr. of Rye, were married there yesterday at Christ's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Edward Johnson performed the ceremony.

LEAD: THE Universal Postal Union declared Friday as World Post Day. While the event spotlights the delivery of mails by postal services worldwide, it also reminds collectors that many nations publicize the hobby through such events.

LEAD: KENNETH PRILL, a Michigan truck driver, wasn't looking to set any legal precedents when a company tractor-trailer with faulty brakes jackknifed with him driving in Tennessee. He simply refused to drive the rig after the accident and reported its condition to state authorities.
LEAD: China issued a harsh attack on the Dalai Lama today, two days after a crowd of Tibetans stoned and burned a police station in Lhasa and at least six people were reported killed.
LEAD: ELSEWHERE in the country the construction of new housing for low-income people depends upon Federal subsidies. But New York City has a golden goose at Battery Park City.
LEAD: FOREIGN SPOKESMEN, APOLO-gists and officials are speaking to us directly, and more often than before.

LEAD: Couple of years ago, after Director of Central Intelligence William Casey threatened to try to jail editors and reporters who dared to print information stamped ''secret,'' I received a call from a Federal law enforcement source.

LEAD: ''History painting'' as a mode of contemporary art is the pretentious premise for a show of big figurative canvases at New York University's Grey Art Gallery (through Oct. 24). The term refers to the highest genre of art from the Renaissance to the mid-19th century - the rendering of elevated themes from classical or Biblical sources that served as vehicles for moral commentary.

LEAD: St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Deborah Merrick Tate, a daughter of Mrs. Herbert DuPuy Merrick of Osterville, Mass., and the late Mr. Merrick, to Charles Albert Brisbane, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seward S. Brisbane of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla.

LEAD: Reviving a tactic that has served him many times in the past, President Reagan today urged supporters of Judge Robert H. Bork to flood Capitol Hill with appeals to confirm him for the Supreme Court.

LEAD: AS an increasing number of New York City rental buildings were converted to co-op ownership in the 80's, it became common for investors to buy from the sponsors units that tenants did not want to purchase. State law permits rent-controlled or rent-stabilized tenants in most conversion situations to remain as renters.
LEAD: Rift Over Lockers At a Paper Plant

LEAD: THE Central Park Tennis House controversy - whether to build new or renovate - has been joined since last spring. Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern had scheduled his decision for Oct. 5, but now says it may be delayed until later this year.
LEAD: An ''impenetrable'' steel-plated van used as an armored car to protect drug dealers in Queens against attempts to muscle into their territory has been seized by the police.

LEAD: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Clarence Fahnestock Michalis of Locust Valley, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter Helen Fahnestock Michalis to Michael Hayden Bonebrake, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Bonebrake of Cleveland Heights, Ohio. A January wedding is planned.
LEAD: William S. Sessions going home yesterday after treatment for an ulcer. He will be sworn in as the bureau's Director on Thursday. (AP)

LEAD: VERSATILE VIRTUOSI To open its new season in Brookville today, the New York Virtuosi Chamber Symphony drops a well-known name in classical music: Menuhin. Jeremy Menuhin, that is, the pianist son of the celebrated violinist father, Yehudi. Mr. Menuhin plays Beethoven's Piano Concerto No. 5 (''Emperor''), and the orchestra, under the baton of Kenneth Klein, performs Mozart's ''Impresario Overture'' and Haydn's Symphony No.

LEAD: I HAVE VISITED SAN FRANCISCO AT least once a year for the last 20 years, yet the trigger of memory still evokes that pristine vision: an ocean liner moving out into the Pacific against the bare hills of Sausalito and, above it, rising from the fog, mystic, wonderful as the sword Excalibur, the graceful red span of the bridge.

LEAD: Undefeated Holy Cross showed its strength today in a 49-7 rout of Colgate, the team regarded as the foremost rival on its schedule. This was the fourth victory for the Crusaders; it was the second defeat in five games for Colgate, a Colonial League rival.
LEAD: NOTHING BUT THE BEST The Struggle for Perfection at the Juilliard School. By Judith Kogan. 239 pp. New York: Random House. $18.95.

LEAD: EVERY TIME I RETURN TO BEIJING AND SEE its skyline growing with cell-blocklike high-rise apartments, drive through its charmless streets and have to breathe the polluted air, I am reminded of how far the city has drifted from its past and wonder how the myth of Beijing as a beautiful city redolent of history has managed to survive its modern esthetic impoverishment.

LEAD: THE proceedings of the Family Court in White Plains are generally closed to the public, but any rider on the County Courthouse elevator knows the stop. It is where all the children get off. The adults hold the doors an extra moment each morning so the children can wedge past the knees and bulging briefcases of the lawyers.

LEAD: IT seemed the stuff of a nightmare from fiction: a fatal disease ravaging the man's body from within, his decision to forgo heroic, life-prolonging steps and the doctors' decision to ignore those wishes and perform their medical magic on the comatose body.

LEAD: Dozens of Iranian Revolutionary Guard speedboats raced in darkness toward a joint Saudi-Kuwaiti oilfield this morning that sends more than $4 million a day to Iraq's war efforts, according to diplomats in the Persian Gulf.

LEAD: Closings in the week ended Sept. 19 MANHATTAN East Midtown $355,000 140 East 56th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,242-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, two exposures; common charge $750, taxes $3,600 (Broker: Arthur P. Brooks Realty) Greenwich Village

LEAD: At a time when nurses are valiantly struggling to gain the professional recognition they have long deserved, we encounter the viewpoint of Rand Araskog, chairman and chief executive officer of I.T.T., who states ''the nurses were young, attractive and friendly.'' Why wasn't any mention made of the intelligence, efficiency and competence of these nurses?

LEAD: An article in the Westchester Weekly today about the county Rent Guidelines Board gives an incorrect date for a vote on new rent levels. The vote, which was scheduled for tomorrow, has been postponed.
LEAD: The Giants have four players on their replacement team with National Football League experience, and the two with the most experience worked in construction for a year before joining the team.

LEAD: Brazil is so large, so varied and so unfinished that books about the country, both literary and academic, tend to offer a glimpse of a region or a slice of the past rather than a global vision of the future or an all-illuminating insight into the present. There are innumerable tomes about the Amazon, for example, but they principally mirror the country's chaotic rush to colonize and exploit its hinterlands.

LEAD: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation met for an hour Friday, their first bargaining session since late August when the union decided to settle first with the Ford Motor Company.

LEAD: Maryruth Randall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Randall Jr. of Hillsdale, N.J., was married at Grace Episcopal Church in Westwood, N.J., yesterday to Robert J. Corker Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Corker of Washington Township, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. H. Gaylord Hitchcock Jr., assisted by the Rev.

LEAD: During the quarter of my life that I have spent abroad, I have learned a good many things that have eased my passage, though some of them, I think, may have taxed my soul. I have, for instance, been able to secure four empty seats on 747's much of the time. I have broken the blockades of desk clerks and have gone over the heads of hotel managers to secure shelter.

LEAD: AN EVENING OUT IN Tokyo can be many things. For Japanese from the provinces, where everything closes more or less at dusk, it may be the bright lights along the Ginza. For Tokyo businessmen, especially if they are entertaining clients, it may be an evening at a geisha establishment followed, perhaps, by a visit to an expensive bar.

LEAD: A storm, complete with swirling winds and relentless rain, reduced tonight's game between Rutgers and Duke to the basics, elevating simple execution to an art form. As a result, Henry Henderson ended more than 54 minutes of minimalist football with no small thing of beauty as he plunged 2 yards for the game's only score and a 7-0 victory for

LEAD: Alexandra Ker Wettlaufer and Arthur Graham Carpenter were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Buffalo. The Rev. David C. Toomey, the bridegroom's brother-in-law, performed the ceremony.

LEAD: IF college athletic directors don't start hiring more black head coaches, the National Football League strike may not be the last unified action by athletes this year - not if Harry Edwards has his way. Edwards, the Berkeley sociologist who advises the commissioner of baseball on racial matters, said that if blacks were not given more college coaching opportunities, he would urge black scholarship players to boycott this season's football bowl games and basketball playoffs.
LEAD: Lawrence C. Merthan, a lawyer and public relations specialist, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Washington. He was 69 years old.

LEAD: A SAVINGS-AND-LOAN association in Pine Bluff, Ark., fails and one of its investments, a vacant new condominium project on Park Avenue, remains empty for years while the Federal Government tries to untangle the bank's finances.
LEAD: THE DAY OF JUDGMENT By Salvatore Satta. Translated by Patrick Creagh. 300 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $19.95.
LEAD: FREE AT LAST What Really Happened When Civil Rights Came to Southern Politics. By Margaret Edds. 277 pp. Bethesda, Md.: Adler & Adler. $18.95.
LEAD: THREE ballets exemplifying Eliot Feld's choreographic eclecticism were on view at Thursday night's performance by the Feld Ballet at the Joyce Theater.
LEAD: Running Scared Starring Gregory Hines and Billy Crystal. Directed by Peter Hyams. 1986. MGM/UA Home Video. 107 minutes. $79.95 ($19.95 as of Oct. 13).
LEAD: The letter from the Governor of Georgia to his counterpart in Maine took 5 1/2 months to arrive and was slightly crumpled, but no one complained.

LEAD: VOTERS will be asked to decide six public questions at the polls on Nov. 3, including three that seek the authority to issue a total of $483 million in bonds for new prisons, a baseball stadium and recreation, cultural and historic-preservation projects.
LEAD: ''BUCKINGHAM PALACE,'' DISTRICT SIX By Richard Rive. 196 pp. New York: Available Press/Ballantine Books. Paper, $5.95.

LEAD: TODAY'S food banks rarely reflect their often-makeshift origins. New Jersey's Community Food Bank, which found its first home in founder Kathleen DiChiara's automobile, has a new 43,000-square-foot warehouse.

LEAD: CONSTITUTIONAL PARADE The village of Mamaroneck celebrates the bicentennial of the Constitution at 1:30 P.M. today with a parade. According to the organizers, it replicates an impromptu parade on Sept. 17, 1787, when the citizens of Philadephia turned out in droves and marched through the streets in support of the Constitution, which had just been signed.

LEAD: MARTHA GRAHAM HAS often told us that ''theater is not a noun, it is a verb.'' The term ''theater'' derives from the Greek, signifying a place where things are to be seen. The connotations of activity and of display in these definitions are especially applicable to dance as a theatrical art. Nobody feels constrained to use the word ''proscenium'' to define the essence of theater.

LEAD: ''EVERYTHING,'' AN operagoer who had just made first contact with Wagner's Wotan was overheard saying, ''is in there.'' The spontaneous exclamation resonates well with both the generalities and the particulars of the role, one of opera's richest and most difficult. Wotan - the Norse god Odin, All-father, War-father - wants to shape the world and everything in it as Wagner wanted to remake not just music but all of art.

LEAD: COYOTES are curious and at least one would appear to have a yen for golf. Mary Hoover, who competed in the Women's Southwest Golf Association match play tournament at the 49er Country Club in Tuscon last week, said that after she hit a ball in Wednesday's round, a coyote came out of the rough, chased the ball until it bounced to a stop, then rolled on top of it and picked it up.

LEAD: William Safire is in good company, but I'm not sure he's right (On Language, ''Hermen Eutic's Original Intent,'' Sept. 6). Many writers have claimed a connection between Hermes and hermeneutics, but the evidence is in short supply. Onions's etymological dictionary sees no connection, tracing hermeneutics back to the Greek hermeneuein, or interpret, and saving Hermes for the origin of hermetic (by way of Hermes Trismegistus, the author of occult science).

LEAD: REMEMBER quiche Lorraine, that savory cheese and bacon tart that once spoke for all that was chic, French and gourmet? Like many other perfectly decent and delicious French foods - boeuf bourguignon, fondue, the souffle - quiche simply wore out its welcome and became a cliche. In time, America's favorite brunch food met its demise through pure and simple banalization.

LEAD: THE International Society for Contemporary Music opened its 1987-88 season Thursday at Symphony Space with a program tracing ''The Influence of Jazz'' in compositions for chamber ensembles, soloists, electronics and tape. LEAD: Through two world wars in which the United States and Germany were adversaries, anti-German feelings ran clear through society. In World War I, hamburger was renamed Salisbury steak and sauerkraut was called Liberty cabbage. In World War II, Spike Jones and his band regularly spit in Der Fuhrer's face over the radio.

LEAD: Office towers in downtown Miami shivered in the sun this week. Windows rattled and floors quivered several times a day. The weather bureau was flooded with calls. Workers were sent home early. The National Earthquake Information Center in Colorado reported no earthquake activity in the region. It noted that South Florida, unlike California, where a severe earthquake killed six people Thursday, is one of the most unlikely places in the United States for an earthquake.

LEAD: I am the friend with MS in Rand Araskog's story. Perhaps the column should have been called ''About Woman.'' Dee has lived with my problem for 25 years plus, raised our four children, been gardner, handyman, etc., with few complaints. With a disease like MS, it is really tougher on the partner. Over 90 percent of MS marriages break up.

LEAD: What put Green River Cemetery on the map was the burial there of the Abstract Expressionist painter Jackson Pollock after a car accident in 1956. The 50-ton memorial boulder, hauled to his knoll-top grave site by friends and fellow artists, drips green with lichens. The stone-imbedded bronze plaque bearing a facsimile of his signature is green now, too, with age.

LEAD: IF putting meat on the table is an important part of your reason for hunting, you had best ignore the ruffed grouse, for there is probably no other upland bird pursued so passionately by so many with so few results.

LEAD: IT will be remembered as Sham Sunday, but maybe it will be the only one. When the National Football League team player representatives meet tonight at an airport hotel in Chicago, maybe they will realize that the strike is crumbling, that 38 players crossed the picket line last Friday, that dozens more will cross it this week, that it's time to realize that the club owners' resistance to free agency isn't worth the loss of salary.

LEAD: The strike version of the Chicago Bears does not compare favorably with the regular Monsters of the Midway, but it got the same results today with a 35-3 rout of the non-union Philadelphia Eagles before only 4,074 fans.
LEAD: After several delays, President Jose Napoleon Duarte and the Marxist-led guerrillas fighting his Government formally met here today for the first time in nearly three years.

LEAD: Three years ago the Atlanta Zoo was considered among the 10 worst in the nation. The cages were filthy, their inhabitants were decrepit and macabre tales were told of animals mysteriously dying, being sold off to circuses or victimized by inept and untrained workers.
LEAD: A loophole in Florida's new law on firearms that allows anyone to carry a weapon in plain view is expected to be eliminated by the State Legislature on Monday, the law's chief proponent says.
LEAD: ''The Publishing Industry's March to Oligopoly,'' a symposium on recent book-publishing mergers, will be held at the New School, 66 West 12th Street, at 8 tonight.
LEAD: Three veteran theater producers have joined forces in a plan to stimulate activity on Broadway by attracting star directors and actors, reducing ticket prices and containing the cost of shows.
LEAD: Two Americans who were detained in Tibet during violent demonstrations last week have been released, the State Department said yesterday.
LEAD: Kertesz Retrospective

LEAD: Nien Cheng, author of ''Life and Death in Shanghai,'' will read from her work today at 7 P.M. at Queens College, Kissena Boulevard and the Long Island Expressway, Flushing. In her autobiography, Mrs. Cheng documents her imprisonment in the late 1960's, during the Cultural Revolution. The reading is part of the school's evening series.

LEAD: Judge Robert H. Bork indicated today that he would not ask President Reagan to withdraw his nomination to the Supreme Court even if it became apparent after the Judiciary Committee vote on Tuesday that the tide had turned inexorably against confirmation by the Senate.

LEAD: The solution to the growing need for child care rests with the elementary-school system, according to a prominent advocate of child welfare. He called for a comprehensive approach, in which many services, including day care, would emanate from the schools.
LEAD: Judge Robert H. Bork, President Reagan's Supreme Court nominee, indicated that he would not ask for the withdrawal of his nomination even if defeat by the full Senate appeared inevitable.

LEAD: Fern J. Finkel and Anthony P. Gentile, an associate and a partner, respectively, in the Manhattan law firm of Philip M. Damashek, were married yesterday at the East River Yacht Club in Long Island City, Queens. Justice Leonard E. Yoswein of State Supreme Court officiated.
LEAD: With interest rates creeping steadily higher, some economists are beginning to worry that the nation will be plunged into a recession next year.

LEAD: Senator Albert Gore Jr., who is seeking the Democratic Presidential nomination, exaggerated his record as an investigative reporter in an interview with an Iowa newspaper, a Memphis newspaper has reported.

LEAD: Moody's Investor Service said today it had raised Chicago's general obligation bonds to an A rating, reflecting the city's economic growth and its determination to balance its budget. The bonds had been rated Baa-1 since March 1984. The change could save the city $5 million to $6 million in interest expenses per $100 million worth of bonds over 25 years, Chicago's comptroller, Ronald Picur, said.

LEAD: On the last day of the season, the Yankees packed and said their good-byes. But there was an uncertainty to the final moments they shared as a team yesterday, as if they could not be sure they would all be together again.

LEAD: This area is known as the apple capital of the world. And with a record harvest expected this fall, that name fits more than ever. But the big question in the orchards that dot the river valleys east of the Cascade Mountains is whether the market can absorb the bountiful crop.

LEAD: Gary Hogeboom, one of the first veterans to defy the National Football League Players Association strike, threw five touchdown passes today as an experienced Indianapolis Colts team routed the strike-depleted Buffalo Bills, 47-6, before 9,860 fans at 80,000-seat Rich Stadium.
LEAD: A. Baird Hastings, a leading biochemist and physiologist, died of heart disease Sept. 24 at Scripps Memorial Hospital in La Jolla, Calif. He was 91 years old.

LEAD: The most powerful aftershock of Thursday's earthquake jolted Southern California early today, causing scattered damage and serving as a reminder of the unpredictability of the violent tremors. The death of a woman from a heart attack was attributed to the quake.

LEAD: If the nomination of Judge Robert Bork to sit on the Supreme Court is doomed, as last-minute White House efforts to raise the ''law and order'' issue suggest, the reasons lie in faulty strategy and sharply changing voting patterns.
LEAD: Deng Pufang, the son of China's top leader, Deng Xiaoping, is headed from New York to Washington tomorrow as the head of a delegation of the China Fund for the Handicapped.

LEAD: An article Saturday about the trial of John A. Zaccaro misstated the political affiliation of Joseph F. Carlino, the first prosecution witness in the trial and a former Speaker of the New York State Assembly. He is a Republican.
LEAD: A task force of the City University of New York has proposed that all students being trained as teachers be required to major in the liberal arts and sciences instead of education.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: AT a time when price volatility is beginning to make some investors nervous, food company stocks are gaining favor because they offer steady growth in revenues, earnings and dividends and a stable group of customers.
LEAD: Seventeen years ago, Robert Din Hatt, also known as Robert Chua, decided to renounce Christianity and convert to Islam. He called himself Rashid Din Hatt Bulanggan.

LEAD: Union representatives from the 28 National Football League teams have scheduled a meeting tonight in Chicago, with expectations rising that the union leaders will drop free agency as a bargaining demand.

LEAD: Not that New York fans need to be reminded, but the National League East championship wasn't the only division title the Mets lost to the St. Louis Cardinals this year. There was also the matter of the division record for home attendance.

LEAD: The week before, Johnny Majors of Tennessee eschewed the 2-point conversion play and an opportunity to win a game against Auburn. Majors ordered a placement kick and accepted a 20-20 tie in a Southeastern Conference game while some of his players and fans grumbled.

LEAD: Senator Strom Thurmond was wrong a generation ago in seeking to block the confirmations of Justices Potter Stewart and Abe Fortas because they read the Constitution in a way that he didn't like. Senators are equally wrong today in opposing Judge Robert H. Bork on the same grounds.

LEAD: The Juilliard Orchestra will open its concert season at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday, with a program of works by Barber, Rachmaninoff and Prokofiev. The pianist Garrick Ohlsson will be soloist for Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 3; Otto-Werner Mueller will conduct. Tickets, at $8 and $5, are available at the Avery Fisher box office or through Center Charge, 874-6770.
LEAD: ''A DANCE FOR TWO,'' Eliot Feld's latest work for the Feld Ballet, is a charming study for two of his most appealing dancers.
LEAD: ''We have a lot of text, but we still have a few T's to cross and I's to dot.'' Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d, on trade agreement with Canada. [ D5:1. ]
LEAD: ''Stay on strike! Stay on strike!'' a large number of Washington Redskin fans chanted today as the third quarter ended in the Redskins' game with the St. Louis Cardinals.

LEAD: The brisk bond market rally on Friday afternoon was enough to reduce note and bond yields by nearly a fifth of a percentage point, even if analysts could not point to any change in economic conditions that justified the move.

LEAD: Turn almost any corner in New York during the coming months, and there's bound to be a bit of the Italy on Stage festival. From West 112th Street to Bowling Green, from Eastern Parkway to Fifth Avenue and the bright lights of Broadway, Italy will display its treasures of art and music, theater and film.

LEAD: At an outdoor cafe in the fashionable Rush Street area here, a waitress told a noontime customer about the day's special. The customer shrieked in horror. It wasn't that the portions were too small, or the prices too large. Instead, it was the rat - too big, too ugly and too close for comfort - crawling across the restaurant floor.

LEAD: John Briggs, a pianist from Yorkshire, England, took the unusual step of engaging Carnegie Hall for his New York debut recital Saturday evening. He brought a program to match: Big works of Schumann, Chopin, Liszt and Prokofiev along with smaller ones by Liszt, Scriabin and Saint-Saens.
LEAD: Dorothy Read Thomas, the widow of James A. Thomas, the tobacco company executive, died Friday of cardiac arrest. She was 96 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: It's the first Monday in October and the Supreme Court convenes for its 197th term, but with only eight justices; the admired Lewis Powell retired in June. There could have been nine justices in place had President Reagan proposed someone like him, or another conservative in the tradition of Justices Felix Frankfurter or John Marshall Harlan.
LEAD: * William S. David was named publisher of Cosmopolitan magazine.

LEAD: ''You can never be satisfied,'' Paul Du Brul wrote in his farewell editorial in the Hunter College student newspaper, ''because there is always so much more that could have been done. But you tried, and in this empty, half apologetic little phrase lies all the satisfaction that people who do things for others will ever have.

LEAD: One of the world's greatest bridge teams has, rather reluctantly, recruited one of the world's greatest players. Michael Lawrence of Kensington, Calif., who has won two world titles and written many excellent books on the game, will compete in the world championships scheduled to start Sunday in Jamaica.
LEAD: The following are excerpts from a summary of the Free Trade Agreement issued by the Office of the United States Trade Representative: Tariffs
LEAD: ALCON LABORATORIES is returning to television today with a $9 million campaign aimed at getting the young women who are the primary users of contact lenses to take better care of them.
LEAD: A high school student newspaper voluntarily turned over photographic negatives of a Ku Klux Klan rally to the Carroll County state's attorney after a local daily newspaper refused.
LEAD: Jean Anouilh, one of France's most prominent and enduring playwrights, died of a heart attack Saturday at the Vaudois University Hospital Center in Lausanne, Switzerland. He was 77 years old.
LEAD: Take away the stadium, the cameras and the fancy uniforms, and the Jets-Cowboys game this afternoon might have been mistaken for a freewheeling, error-ridden semi-pro game.

LEAD: Two Texas energy companies filed a $1 billion lawsuit Friday against Ray L. Hunt and the Hunt Oil Company, charging that Mr. Hunt had unlawfully interfered with an agreement between them and the Government of Yemen.
LEAD: Many American business leaders expressed strong support yesterday for the sweeping free trade agreement reached by negotiators for the United States and Canada.

LEAD: The United States and Canada have agreed to an extensive trade pact that would stimulate economic activity in both countries by eliminating tariffs and other trade barriers before the end of the century.

LEAD: The Mets, who lost the battle for first place three days ago, fought and won the battle for second place today when they closed the season by rallying with five runs in the ninth inning to defeat the St. Louis Cardinals, 11-6.
LEAD: Mexico's ruling party today named Carlos Salinas de Gortari, a 39-year-old economist, as its candidate to succeed President Miguel de la Madrid in December 1988.

LEAD: Iran said today that it had staged intensive naval exercises in the Persian Gulf over the weekend, in an apparent reference to military movements that alarmed Saudi Arabia and prompted an American warship to steam toward the area of activity.

LEAD: There were about four minutes left in the second quarter when one fan got up from his end-zone seat and began his climb to the exits. Another touchdown by the Dallas Cowboys -their third straight - quickened his pace, but it was not until he reached the parking-lot gate that he finally took off the gas mask he was wearing.

LEAD: ''The Death of Lottie Shapiro'' is a long and elaborate song cycle celebrating the poems of Bette Distler. The music is by the poet's son, Jed; Mr. Distler, who is also a pianist, joined five sopranos in a performance of the piece's 29 numbers at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday night.

LEAD: David W. C. Clark, a New York lawyer implicated in the insider trading circle that included a former Wall Street Journal columnist, R. Foster Winans, is scheduled to go on trial today in a Federal courtroom in lower Manhattan.
LEAD: New York City and Federal officials yesterday announced details of an ambitious voter registration drive, with the goal of enrolling two million new voters in New York City.
LEAD: The longtime president of the N.A.A.C.P in New Jersey, defeated in a bid for reelection on Saturday, will try to invalidate the vote results in court, her attorney said today.
LEAD: Three recent disappearances and murders have galvanized residents of normally quiescent Staten Island into a state of mobilization.

LEAD: Paul McMahon, a singer and songwriter, treated performance art as low-budget music video Thursday in his hourlong ''Song of the Statues,'' at Home, 44 Walker Street, below Canal Street. As he parodies songwriters from Brecht and Weill to Philip Glass, he dons various costumes and shticks as the context demands.

LEAD: Thirty years after the launching of the first Sputnik began the space age, Soviet scientists celebrated with a weekend-long display of space glasnost and an appeal for international cooperation in exploring the solar system.

LEAD: Alarmed by a spate of amendments that would limit the Pentagon's arms imports, the Defense Department has named Dennis Kloske, the Deputy Under Secretary for policy and resources, to be its ''trade and defense competition advocate.''

LEAD: In much of New York City, animals are not welcome. There are ''no dogs'' signs in store windows and ''no pet'' clauses in city leases. Yesterday, however, animals were given center stage at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, a church that often draws its inspiration from the Middle Ages.

LEAD: The State Choir of Armenia knows how to deliver a show. At touring strength, as heard in Avery Fisher Hall Saturday afternoon, it is an ensemble of some 75 rich, firm voices, comfortable alike in rousing folk and patriotic music, operatic excerpts, backup vocals for a crooner and new music of moderate difficulty.

LEAD: William H. Spoor has always been a name to conjure with at the Pillsbury Company. Now the 64-year-old retired chairman is creating ripples again with his appointment as head of the board's executive committee.
LEAD: ''We've had enough of Sasso,'' said Marjorie Tyler, 71 years old, her face alive with indignation.

LEAD: Given the pivotal position that Justice Lewis F. Powell Jr. occupied at the Supreme Court's ideological center, the Court may well be unable to resolve some significant issues until the vacancy created by his retirement is filled.

LEAD: Laurie Beth Millman, the vice president of marketing and the product group director at the Schieffelin & Somerset Company, a subsidiary of the Moet-Hennessy United States Corporation in New York, and Stephen Freedman, president of Vinmark, a wine brokerage in Marblehead, Mass., were married yesterday at the Harrison Conference Center in Glen Cove, L.I.

LEAD: ''STAR TREK'' is back - not as a rerun or a feature film, but as a syndicated series called ''Star Trek: The Next Generation.'' Trekkies will eagerly recall that the original series had its premiere in September 1966. In fact, the series was not terribly successful in terms of ratings. But its hard-core fans were devoted and fiercely protective, fending off at least one cancellation of the series with a letters campaign.
LEAD: A lot of star power occupied the Senate Dining Room on Friday as political stars mixed it up with the stars of stage and screen.

LEAD: In the locker rooms at Giants Stadium after today's Jets-Cowboys game, regular players explained their reasons for crossing the picket lines while the replacement players talked about the experience of playing in a regular National Football League game.

LEAD: Over All continued her dominance of New York's 2-year-old fillies and gave her trainer a sweep of the weekend's Grade I juvenile stakes by scoring a 5 3/4-length victory in the $136,900 Matron Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park.

LEAD: The Chinese authorities imposed a curfew today and tried to stop at least one busload of foreign tourists from leaving this Tibetan capital after pro-independence demonstrations in which at least six people were reported killed.

LEAD: A witness to a Queens shootout last month that left four people wounded was shot to death early yesterday in an execution-like killing that may have been intended to prevent her from testifying before a grand jury, the police said.

LEAD: Joseph P. Kennedy 2d began his career in the House of Representatives in just about the least desired suite of offices in the entire Congress but with television crews from as far away as Japan pressing at the door.

LEAD: With the threat of scores of lawsuits hanging over them, Bridgeport city officials, as well as contractors, engineers and insurers involved in the collapse of an apartment building here last April, are anxiously awaiting a Federal report on the cause of the disaster.

LEAD: Lee Rambeau, a daughter of Sallie Mae Rambeau of Winter Park, Fla., and the late Leroy Rambeau, was married yesterday to Wildred David Kemp, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Leroy Kemp of Tulsa, Okla. Justice Ivan Warner of State Supreme Court in the Bronx officiated at Alder Manor in Yonkers.
LEAD: THE LAST INTELLECTUALS. American Culture in the Age of Academe. By Russell Jacoby. 290 pages. Basic Books. $18.95.
LEAD: IT came as a surprise; it usually does. One minute he stood there, in the prime of beard, with a mustache, too. The next minute, not even an upper-lip hair was left standing.

LEAD: An official guest from China came to the Parrinos' home here in this Westchester County village today, and as he pushed himself from room to room in a wheelchair, he commented on the wide, smooth hallways and the picture-window views of the outdoors.

LEAD: Treasury auctions this week consist of today's regular sale of three- and six-month bills, followed by four-year notes tomorrow and seven-year notes on Wednesday. The Treasury plans to sell $12.8 billion of three- and six-month bills, $7.25 billion of four-year notes and $6.75 billion of seven-year notes.

LEAD: The farmhands included a 5-year-old, a teen-ager, a middle-aged couple and a grandmother approaching 80. City dwellers all, they had gathered in Columbia County, New York, for a rural ceremony: pressing cider from the first apples of the season.

LEAD: Justice Department officials say that, despite recent disputes in New York and elsewhere, a special Federal program to relocate trial witnesses has led to important criminal convictions and met with relatively few complaints from protected witnesses.

LEAD: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan called today on Governor Cuomo of New York and Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey to run as favorite-son candidates for President as a way to keep the 1988 Democratic Presidential race open until the party's convention in Atlanta.

LEAD: IN every film he's ever made, Alain Resnais has been exploring cinema techniques with such invention that technique has sometimes become the end instead of the means. LEAD: GOLF England Upsets Scotland: England silenced a huge gallery of Scots and beat the home team, 2-1, to win the $1 million Dunhill Cup team tournament yesterday at St. Andrew's. In the consolation match, Curtis Strange shot a 10-under-par 62 against Greg Norman of Australia as the United States won third place, 2-1.

LEAD: THERE is a new peace movement afoot in hockey, one designed to eliminate the bench-clearing brawls. Although they occur with just about a third of the frequency of baseball brawls, they are perceived by hockey administrators to perpetuate the myth of their sport as a wrestling match on ice skates.

LEAD: Helene Curtis Industries of Chicago, whose Suave line of personal care products was at Backer & Spielvogel before its merger with Ted Bates Worldwide, has announced the line has been reassigned to Bayer Bess Vanderwarker & Flynn, also of Chicago.

LEAD: The world's stock markets continued to show strength in the sixth year of the bull market, although the pace of expansion slowed. In the quarter ending Sept. 30, stock prices worldwide rose by 5.7 percent, according to figures compiled by Morgan Stanley Capital International.
LEAD: THE Blue Jays are dead, as dead as the octopus that came hurtling out of the upper deck and landed near the Toronto dugout in the seventh inning yesterday.

LEAD: Lee A. Iacocca, the chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, was looking for a good investment several years ago, so he turned to his friend, Donald J. Trump. Mr. Trump first found a small Manhattan hotel at the bargain price of $10 million. Too high, said Mr. Iacocca.
LEAD: To the Editor:

Soicher of Old Westbury, L.I., and Rona Soicher of Great Neck, L.I., was married to Gregory Slote, the son of Mildred Slote of Kings Point, L.I., and the late Dr. Lawrence Slote. Rabbi Herbert Richtman officiated.

LEAD: The slight fracture of the lower jaw suffered by John Vanbiesbrouck during practice Saturday will not prevent the Ranger goalie from being available to the team for its season opener against the Pittsburgh Penguins on Thursday. But the injury does make it likely that Bob Froese, the other Ranger goaltender, will start.

LEAD: The earliest snowstorm on record struck New York, Connecticut and other parts of New England yesterday, burying some areas in more than a foot of snow that closed roads and airports, knocked out power to more than 300,000 homes and turned russet autumn to wintry solitude.

LEAD: Sir Peter Medawar, the British doctor who shared the Nobel Prize for Medicine in 1960 and later in life was recognized as a scientific philosopher and writer, died Friday in London's Royal Free Hospital. He was 72 years old.

LEAD: Fans returning from a concert by a British punk rock band knocked a state ferry out of commission early Saturday when they chopped apart tables and chairs with an ax and ripped tiles from the ceiling, the authorities said. Five people were arrested. The fans were returning from a concert by the British group GBH, which reportedly stands for Grevious Bodily Harm.

Billed as an ''African dance opera,'' the production by a company from Zaire combined dance with song, chanting and percussion music.

LEAD: The Sikh religion's holiest shrine, which used to bustle with thousands of worshipers, sits quiet and nearly empty here. Sikhs and others say fear keeps them away.
LEAD: Eight years after he began as a freshman at Indiana University and six years after he left as a full-time student, Isiah Thomas recently completed his course work for a Bachelor of Arts degree.

LEAD: The Supreme Court, with one seat empty and the possibility of 4-to-4 deadlocks or postponed decisions in key cases, opens its new term Monday facing an array of the politically charged issues that have fueled the battle over Judge Robert H. Bork's nomination.

LEAD: Lisa Karen Gornick, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at Yale University, and Kenneth Joseph Hollenbeck, a lawyer with the Community Health Law Project, a public-interest legal corporation in East Orange, N.J., were married yesterday. LEAD: When Canadians awoke today to news of the free trade agreement with the United States, supporters and opponents of the pact agreed on one thing: that Prime Minister Brian Mulroney had embarked on an imposing gamble with his own future, and possibly with the country's as well.

LEAD: Lukas Foss will the guest of honor tonight at a concert featuring a New York premiere of one of his works, at 8 o'clock at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The concert is part of the hall's ''Composers and Company'' series devoted to 20th-century music, which began last month with a concert of music by David Del Tredici.
LEAD: Elizabeth Hanford Dole embarks this week on one of the most unusual roles of her career: she will serve as an unpaid, full-time campaign worker for her husband's Presidential drive.

LEAD: It took Dorothy Herman six months to find a contractor to remodel her kitchen and build a new deck on her home here. Now she has to wait four more months before the contractor, whose work she likes, has time to renovate her bathrooms.

LEAD: New York City's Human Resources Administration is preparing a five-year plan that could eliminate the use of welfare hotels for homeless families, according to the head of the agency, William J. Grinker.

LEAD: From his father comes a passion for politics; from his mother, a delight in the intellectual rigors of economics. Throughout his short but successful career, friends say, Carlos Salinas de Gortari has sought to satisfy the demands of two often contradictory disciplines.

LEAD: Ripe red apples on the ground in many New York State orchards are a sign that difficult financial times may lie ahead for some farmers.

LEAD: The sweeping free-trade agreement between the United States and Canada approved here late Saturday night will not only set the terms of commerce between the world's two largest trading partners but will establish a benchmark for the reforms America is seeking in the international trading system.

LEAD: The Mets were taking on the Phillies in Philadelphia, the Cardinals were playing the Expos in St. Louis, and Harold Brodsky, a diehard Mets fan, was at a Broadway show in New York the other night when he got to wondering how the National League East pennant race was going. So at intermission, with no radio, television or telephone in sight, he reached into his pocket to find out.
