LEAD: A dozen Mexican banks operate in this fast-growing industrial and commercial center on the Rio Grande. For years, though, people here, like tens of thousands of other Mexicans, have routinely converted their pesos into dollars and deposited them in United States banks just across the border.

LEAD: THE American Chamber Opera's triple bill Friday evening at the Marymount Manhattan College Theater offered a group of short scores that promised interest, but proved unfortunately somewhat dreary in the event. None of the pieces sent one home eager for more, except in one sense: Putting them on the stage is the only real way to test new operas, and so the company's efforts are firmly in the right place.

LEAD: The Veterans Administration said Friday that it was raising its maximum interest rate for new federally backed V.A. home mortgages to 11 percent. The rise, which will take effect Monday, will be the V.A.'s fourth rate increase this year. The agency said it was making the change to bring its rate in line with the overall mortgage market, in which rates have risen in recent weeks.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: A STORM is in progress during most of ''The Tavern.''
LEAD: Wall Street's ''tombstone'' ads may look stately, but the politicking that goes on before they ever appear in print can get downright undignified.
LEAD: Adrian Lyne had a hangover.

LEAD: The Supreme Court today refused to strip the Statue of Liberty of its status as a New Yorker. The Court, without comment, turned away a move by a two New Jerseyans to claim jurisdiction over the landmark for their state.

LEAD: As the result of losing Burger King's huge $200 million advertising account, J. Walter Thompson has begun to trim its staff. Sources at the agency indicate that some 100 staff members were dropped, mostly from the New York office, which handled the largest part of the work for the Pillsbury Company subsidiary.

LEAD: The Federal Government and more than 20 health organizations today issued the nation's first detailed guidelines for identifying and treating people whose blood cholesterol levels are high enough to require medical treatment.

LEAD: AFTER months of hunting for an investor to make a major infusion of capital in Pan American World Airways, a coalition of unions at the airline and their investment banker, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., may be getting closer to their goal.

LEAD: The Zayre Corporation said yesterday that Edward J. DeBartolo Jr., a prominent shopping center developer, had told the retailer that he intended to buy at least 73,000 more shares of its common stock and may later try to acquire control.

LEAD: Just one day after the Baltimore Orioles finished their American League season with the third-worst record (66-96) in their 34-year-history, there was a big shake-up in the Orioles' front office yesterday. Edward Bennett Williams, the owner, announced he had dismissed Hank Peters, the general manager for the last 12 years, and Tom Giordano, the director of the farm system.

LEAD: Representatives of Botswana, Kenya and other African nations today criticized members of the Security Council who support sanctions against Iran as a means of ending the gulf war but refuse to impose similar measures against South Africa over apartheid or its occupation of South-West Africa.
LEAD: The biggest beneficiaries of the recent unrest in Tibet may be officials in Beijing who are opposed to the pace of China's liberalization, in the view of political analysts in Hong Kong.

LEAD: The Detroit Tigers, who won the American League East title in the final days of the season with a three-game sweep of the Toronto Blue Jays, and the St. Louis Cardinals, who replaced the Mets atop the National League East, are favored to meet in the World Series, according to oddsmakers in Las Vegas,

LEAD: New Jersey's Casino Control Commission licensed Caesars World Inc. today to operate Caesars Casino Hotel in Atlantic City for another year, on the condition that it make a good-faith effort to employ more blacks and women. The vote was 5 to 0 in favor of the relicensing.

LEAD: Any dancing at the 10th annual Democratic Gala tomorrow night will have to be in the aisles. The demand for tickets to the $1,500-a-plate affair has been so heavy that the space that had been reserved for the dance floor in the International Ballroom of the Washington Hilton hotel has been sold to accommodate more tables.
LEAD: Despite the cut-rate financing offered in late summer by the Big Three auto makers, the 1987 model year ended with total passenger vehicle sales about 4 percent below the record totals of 1986.
LEAD: Ladies and gentlemen, meet the beetles.

LEAD: TELEVISION drama is curiously reluctant to tackle, frankly and sympathetically, the devastating effects of AIDS on homosexuals. ''An Early Frost,'' broadcast nearly two years ago, was a notable exception. Otherwise, television dramas about AIDS have preferred to focus on nonhomosexual victims of the disease.
LEAD: Stocks ended mixed yesterday as worry over higher interest rates and inflation erased an early gain on the Dow Jones industrial average.

LEAD: Jimy Williams, manager of the Toronto Blue Jays, and his entire coaching staff have been signed to contracts for the 1988 season, the team announced yesterday. His staff includes Cito Gaston, batting coach; Al Widmar, pitching coach; John McLaren, third base coach; Billy Smith, first base coach, and John

LEAD: How did Bob Woodward of The Washington Post manage to get into the hospital room of William J. Casey, the former Director of Central Intelligence, for a deathbed interview reported in the new Woodward book ''Veil''? Well, the irreverent Capitol Hill tabloid Roll Call has come forward with some suggestions.

LEAD: Surveillance Drone Delayed The Army has delayed production of its main unmanned surveillance aircraft because its operators could not spot many targets in a test. Page A16. Help for Airline Passengers The House approved consumer-protection measures for airline passengers. The Senate is expected to back similar legislation.
LEAD: It had been an unsettled couple of months for Willi Plett, days spent playing hockey with unfamiliar faces, nights spent in a strange motel.

LEAD: A woman and her 16-year-old son were found dead in their Bronx apartment yesterday, and the woman's other son was later charged with the murders, the police said. A police spokesman, Sgt. John Venetucci, said the bodies of Kathleen Wiggins, 46 years old, and her 16-year-old son, Sean, were discovered in the apartment at 1686 Clay Avenue in the Tremont section of the Bronx, by Thomas Wiggins, Mrs.

LEAD: Fashion is exploding in all possible directions. Not too long ago audiences complained that Italian clothes looked alike; you couldn't tell the designers without a score card. The arrival of short skirts has changed all that. It has spurred a burst of inventiveness as designers tried to come to terms with the new proportions.

LEAD: The New York State Energy Research and Development Corporation offered $49.1 million of tax-exempt bonds yesterday on behalf of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

LEAD: COME now to a white-sand beach, modern hotel and soft tropic murmurs. Come to Nicaragua. ''Vacation Nicaragua'' says United States tourists will have a swell time; they can sit in the sun and find political redemption, too. ''Vacation Nicaragua,'' on Channel 13 at 11 o'clock tonight, is gorgeously done propaganda.
LEAD: A ruling in favor of International Corona Resources in an Ontario appeals court means the company is the owner of a mine that is expected to be one of North America's biggest gold producers.

LEAD: The New York Telephone Company yesterday offered $300 million of 9 5/8 percent notes, due in 1992, at a price of 99.824 to yield 9.67 percent through a group of underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

LEAD: While Jonathan Boyer was calling an end to his international cycling career when he finished 68th in the Nissan Classic tour of Ireland on Sunday in Dublin, Greg LeMond was using his 44th-place finish in the same race as a building block in a comeback from injuries and illness that ruined his 1987 season.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: WHILE on the surface of the moon in 1971, an American astronaut paused before a television camera to demonstrate that Galileo in the 17th century had it right about the force of gravity when he observed that ''in a medium totally devoid of resistance all bodies would fall with the same speed.''

LEAD: Thirty-three more oil and gas drilling rigs were working in the United States last week, bringing the total to 1,127, Baker Hughes said today. The previous week, the oilfield toolmaker's rig count had dropped by 7, to 1,094. A year ago the total was 818.
LEAD: For the first weekday in memory, John Derrick, the rural mail deliverer here, did not complete his duly appointed rounds.

LEAD: Gibbons, Green, Van Amerongen Ltd. said today that it planned to buy Argonaut Group Inc. for about $620 million, a deal that apparently ends a long courtship for the workers' compensation insurer.

LEAD: ''It is becoming increasingly difficult to avoid the conclusion that someone advising the President is trying to torpedo the peace process.'' House Speaker Jim Wright, discussing Central America. [ A1:1. ]

LEAD: NINETEEN EIGHTY-SEVEN will be remembered as a year in which the New York Film Festival, in the course of celebrating its 25th anniversary, went a little batty. It offered ''Jackie Chan's Police Story,'' a work of karate-based comedy hardly in keeping with the festival's usual fare. It presented a rock documentary and concert film (''Chuck Berry Hail!
LEAD: A Federal judge has postponed the one-year sentence imposed on C. McClain Haddow, a former Department of Health and Human Services official convicted of conflict-of-interest charges.

LEAD: A golden autumn sun melted much of the snow that Sunday's freak storm dumped across New York, Connecticut and other parts of New England yesterday, but thousands of homes remained without power, hundreds of schools and businesses were closed and road and air travel was still limited.
LEAD: The Supreme Court agreed today to review the constitutionality of a New York City law that prohibits large social clubs from excluding women as members.
LEAD: The French campaign for next spring's presidential election may well turn out to confirm a watershed in the history of republican France two centuries after the revolution.

LEAD: President Jose Napoleon Duarte and the Marxist-led guerrillas fighting his Government were reportedly discussing ''substantive issues'' today during their second day of talks to end the eight-year-old civil war.

LEAD: A plow clearing a stretch of the Taconic State Parkway yesterday near Austerlitz, N.Y. As milder temperatures returned, the sun melted most of the snow, but thousands of homes and businesses remained without power. Page B2. (AP)
LEAD: Rick Pitino made his debut as coach of the Knicks this morning by conducting the first practice for rookies and free agents.

LEAD: Lieut. Col. Desi Bouterse, who seized power in the small South American country of Suriname seven years ago, says if it were just up to him there would be no elections in Suriname for at least five years.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: THE 10th anniversary of the death of Roberto Rossellini, the master innovator of the Italian cinema, will be marked by the New York Film Festival tonight at 9:15 with the retrospective showing of two films virtually unknown in this country.
LEAD: Saudi Arabia has made a $5 million gift to the actor Paul Newman to help establish a camp in Connecticut for critically ill children.

LEAD: A fire injured 10 firefighters and caused $2 million in damage at a shopping center Saturday, the authorities said. Officials said two stores were destroyed and six damaged in the blaze, which sent flames 100 feet into the air. The cause of the fire was not immediately determined.

LEAD: For 17 years, Beate Gordon has been a sort of cultural detective. She travels to Asia each summer, ferreting out virtuoso performers of traditional arts and arranging for them to tour the United States.

LEAD: Three marines were killed Sunday when the car in which they were riding became airborne while exiting Interstate 395 and struck a tree, breaking the auto into two pieces, the police said. The identities of the men, stationed at the Quantico Marine Base, were not immediately released.

LEAD: IN the world of spreadsheets, Microsoft Excel is the standard for the Apple Macintosh and Lotus 1-2-3 is the standard for everyone else. Until today the division was neat and clean. Lotus 1-2-3 did not run on the Mac and Excel did not run on the PC.

LEAD: On the eve of a new Koch administration effort to remove homeless people with severe mental disturbances from the streets, a New York City health official said that overcrowding in municipal psychiatric emergency rooms had reached crisis levels and that the state was not doing enough to help out.
LEAD: The Army has delayed production of its premier unmanned surveillance aircraft after operators proved unable to use it effectively in a 17-week trial last summer.

LEAD: Catchers (Average, home runs, r.b.i.) 8 Mike Heath (.281, 8, 33) Will start playoff opener against Twins' left-hander, Frank Viola, thereby putting Matt Nokes on bench for at least one game. Power numbers don't rival Nokes's, but he's a veteran who handles pitchers well and has strong arm.
LEAD: The Brooklyn District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman, subpoenaed records yesterday from the State Assembly's political arm, the House Operations Committee.
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: The Allegheny Beverage Corporation tentatively reduced the price of its Service America Corporation subsidiary by $50 million, to $450 million, in weekend negotiations with the management group seeking to buy the unit, Allegheny said. Allegheny and the group, known as the Servam Corporation, reopened discussions on the price after receiving lower revenue estimates.

LEAD: IN ''China Dream,'' a celebrated Chinese actress immigrates to the United States, is unable to continue her career and finds herself becoming nostalgic for the life she thought she had in her homeland. From this material, William H. Sun and Faye C. Fei, a husband-and-wife team of playwrights, have fashioned an unsophisticated little play that strives for wistfulness.

LEAD: Lewis Brown last played basketball for Nevada-Las Vegas in 1977. The 6-foot-10-inch, 32-year-old center is now at the Los Angeles Clippers' training camp. So is David Thirdkill, who has a championship ring from the Boston Celtics, as well as Jim Lampley, Aubrey Sherrod and Willie White.
LEAD: The chairman of a cable television company that John A. Zaccaro is accused of trying to extort testified yesterday that he never heard or saw Mr. Zaccaro do anything wrong.

LEAD: Looking back, the debate over the last two weeks about whether the networks should televise the first National Football League replacement games now seems silly. Whatever their reasons - financial or legal - NBC and CBS were right to show Sunday's games.
LEAD: Opponents of the Seabrook nuclear power plant in New Hampshire today disrupted Government hearings that could determine whether the dormant plant will be allowed to operate.
LEAD: The House of Representatives today approved a package of consumer-protection measures for airline passengers.

LEAD: Persuaded that Cheryl Pierson was sexually abused by her father, a State Supreme Court justice sentenced the 18-year-old woman today to six months in jail for her role in planning her father's murder.

LEAD: Bond mutual funds produced a negative return to investors during the third quarter and the mutual fund industry in general did not shine, according to Lipper Analytical Services, which tracks the performance of 372 fixed-income funds and 1,341 funds over all.

LEAD: Portraits of President Hosni Mubarak hung from iron fence posts and wires strung across streets and even covered the dusty trees, but the polling station at the Ali Abdul Latif primary school for girls was a quiet place at 11 o'clock this morning.
LEAD: To the Editor:
LEAD: * AMR Corp. elected as a director Edward A. Brennan, chairman and chief executive of Sears, Roebuck & Co.
LEAD: The firefighters' physical test left standing yesterday by the Supreme Court is the key factor in deciding who joins the department.

LEAD: THE study of defective genes that help trigger cancers, one of the most rapidly advancing fields of modern biological science, is now beginning to yield its first practical applications, aiding in the selection of treatments for some cancers.
LEAD: The Atomic Energy Authority today announced the start of a cleanup operation at the plutonium-producing reactor that was the scene in 1957 of one of the world's worst nuclear accidents.
LEAD: Six nights a week Mildred Green dispatched cabs through the drug-scarred streets of South Jamaica, Queens.

LEAD: In much of India, he has become almost a cult figure, a popular symbol among the many who want terrorism crushed by force. But in the northern state of Punjab, where such terrorism is a daily fact of life, he is No. 1 on the so-called ''hit list'' of Sikh extremists.

LEAD: A FEW weeks ago this space mentioned Compute!'s PC Magazine, a publication with its articles in conventional printed form but with programs supplied on a disk sold as an integral part of the package. Well, Uptime is a computer magazine supplied entirely on a disk.

LEAD: $ Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 8.75 8.75 7.50 DISCOUNT RATE 6.00 6.00 5.50 FEDERAL FUNDS 7.47 7.42 5.78 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 6.68 6.67 5.05 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 6.86 6.85 5.15 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 9.56 9.45 7.05 30-YR.
LEAD: Who will educate Desarae Paganelli?
LEAD: Staten Island Republicans elected Olga Igneri as their county leader last night, six days after their first attempt turned into a shouting, shoving melee.

LEAD: Texaco Inc. asked the United States trustee overseeing its bankruptcy proceedings to eliminate one of the two creditors committees. But officials of the Pennzoil Company, which won a $10.53 billion court judgment against Texaco in a dispute over Getty Oil and is co-head of the committee that Texaco wants to dissolve, said it would oppose the request.

LEAD: Turning the television channels Sunday in search of a football game, this reporter came across on the screen a man in a hurry who was carrying a small brown object that looked like a football. Or was it a roasted chicken?
LEAD: To the Editor:

LEAD: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, told Congress today that banks, victimized by new technology and ''frozen'' in a regulatory structure developed more than 50 years ago, were losing their competitive battle with other financial institutions and needed to obtain new powers to restore a balance.

LEAD: Successful college soccer coaches have finally come to realize that their players may have missions that extend beyond the collegiate horizon -and the realization has benefited the country's national programs.

LEAD: The Bowery Savings Bank, one of New York's oldest savings banks, was sold yesterday, less than two years after a group of investors helped rescue it from the brink of collapse, with Federal backing.

LEAD: The wife of Anthony M. Scotto, the former president of the Brooklyn Longshoreman's Local 1814, has been receiving as much as $30,000 a year for a no-show job with the local's Political Action Fund, according to the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor.
LEAD: Unemployment inched down to 5.8 percent in September with hardly a whiff of inflation, and the White House is crowing.

LEAD: A cylinder of ice nearly a mile and a half long, painstakingly drawn from the Antarctic icecap by a Soviet and French scientific expedition, has documented 160,000 years of the earth's climate, revealing a surprisingly precise connection between changes in temperature and in the amount of carbon dioxide in the air.

LEAD: Whitey Herzog said today that the St. Louis Cardinals would open the playoff for the National League pennant Tuesday night without Jack Clark, their injured power hitter, and predicted that Clark would not start against the San Francisco Giants until the sixth game.

LEAD: Waring & LaRosa, long a Fisher-Price agency, has been named to handle its Brand Licensed Products for infant and toddler businesses. The assignment was formerly at Towne Silverstein Rotter. Billing figures were unavailable.
LEAD: Before the National Football League players went on strike, the Giants lost their first two games of the season. Tonight, in their first game with a replacement team, they lost again.
LEAD: A joint venture between two cable-television companies was announced yesterday, paving the way for about 180,000 homes in southern Queens to receive cable.

LEAD: The last time Rick Reuschel passed this way, in places with red, white and blue bunting hung out on October days and nights, the experience was not much fun. Three years ago this month he was a Chicago Cub who could do nothing more than watch. Now he can help the San Francisco Giants reach the World Series for the first time in 25 years.
LEAD: THE agency business is amazing at times for its ease of entry. All it seems to take is creative people with the ability to sell themselves to advertisers.

LEAD: Iraqi planes struck five tankers, one of them the world's largest, in raids Monday, on Iranian oil targets at both ends of the Persian Gulf, and Iran fired two a missiles into Baghdad, one Monday and one early today, for the first time in nearly eight months.

LEAD: A person who switches drinks depending on his mood, or who likes to experiment with fashion, or who buys expensive goods because he feels he's worth it - that's a ''fashion-focused'' person, as defined by a proprietary study done by Simmons Market Research for Us magazine.
LEAD: General Assembly P.M.

LEAD: A 17-agency contest for the Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey ad account has ended with Gianettino & Meredith of Short Hills, N.J., as the victor. Billings are expected to be about $4 million, the agency said.
LEAD: One of the leading commanders of Miskito Indian guerrillas fighting in Nicaragua has agreed to end his campaign against the Sandinista Government.
LEAD: China said today that its Air Force shot down a Vietnamese jet fighter this afternoon after it twice intruded into Chinese air space.
LEAD: What has happened to the War Powers Act?

LEAD: Since the end of testimony about Judge Robert H. Bork before the Judiciary Committee, 20 members of the Senate, including some influential undecided senators, have announced their positions on his nomination to the Supreme Court. Following are excerpts from some of the statements of the 4 senators who favor confirmation and the 16 who oppose it.

LEAD: Amadou-Mahtar M'Bow, whose 13 years as director general of Unesco has split the organization, is favored to emerge as the winner when Unesco's executive board begins voting for a new director general Tuesday.

LEAD: The Manhattan District Attorney's office has subpoenaed Church of Scientology records about Robert E. Chambers Jr., who twice sought counseling at the organization's Celebrity Center in Manhattan.

LEAD: ''I still feel that I can pitch and feel the need to pitch,'' said Dan Quisenberry, the former king of the Kansas City Royals' bullpen, who asked the Royals to trade him Sunday after finishing the season with a 4-1 record, a 2.76 earned-run average, but only eight saves in 49 innings pitched. ''I can't let that hope die within myself and have to pursue that hope somewhere else.
LEAD: ''WE'RE not represented the way I'd like to be,'' said Calvin Klein, discussing his plans to open stores around the country. The first should open next spring in Dallas.

LEAD: To save a free-trade pact with Canada, the Reagan Administration agreed that a Canadian-American dispute settlement panel could review acts of Congress and authorize Canadian trade retaliation if those acts ''violate the spirit'' of the pact.

LEAD: It takes some snooping to find the favorite bookstore of Washington's intelligence professionals. The store, the National Intelligence Book Center, doesn't advertise, and its collection of almost 700 titles is tucked away in a small, windowless room on the 10th floor of a downtown office building.

LEAD: As the National Football League owners intensified the pressure on striking players today with several procedural changes, union leaders met here tonight on the 14th day of the strike to review their options, including dropping the demand for free agency.

LEAD: Mexico's incumbent President acted reasonably in choosing Carlos Salinas Gortari, an economist, to succeed him next year. His country remains gripped by its worst economic crisis in a half century. But the anointed technocrat will have to spend as much time attending to an equally severe crisis - the faltering political credibility of the PRI, the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party.

LEAD: Jane K. Butcher, the first woman ever appointed to the board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, died after a long illness last Thursday. She was 64 years old and lived in White Plains.

LEAD: Mayor Koch shaking hands with Donald J. Trump during ceremony celebrating Israel's 40th anniversary. The two have been feuding publicly and the handshake occurred ''at the appropriate moment -when it was the thing to do,'' said the Mayor. Both declined to repeat the act for photographers. With them were, from left: Peter F.

LEAD: For all the ominous drama of warships in the Persian Gulf and the promise of a new superpower missile treaty, America's workaday foreign relations still depend heavily on its neighbors. Ronald Reagan acknowledged that in his speech opening his Presidential campaign in 1979; he talked at length about a ''North American accord.

LEAD: The Israeli-American discussions on the joint security assistance program being held this week are perhaps the most significant ever between both countries. They represent a critical opportunity for America to minimize the hardship and dislocation that might result from Israel's cancellation of its
LEAD: There is nothing novel about a retailer running a toll-free number in a print ad in hopes of attracting the less adventuresome or combative shopper. It's called telemarketing.
LEAD: The Environmental Protection Agency announced today that it would impose new controls to reduce the discharge of a wide range of toxic chemicals into the nation's surface waters.

LEAD: The USG Corporation came under takeover attack yesterday for the second time in less than a year as Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown, multimillionaire Texans, announced that they owned a 9.83 percent stake and might seek control of the nation's biggest gypsum producer.
LEAD: The rate of violent crime dropped 6.3 percent from 1985 to 1986, the Government says in a new report, but some experts say a five-year decline in crime trends appears to be bottoming out.

LEAD: The board of directors of the Negro Ensemble Company has named Leon B. Denmark producing director of the 20-year-old theater group, the chairman, Lucius P. Gregg, announced yesterday. Mr. Denmark, who formerly was managing director, takes over day-to-day artistic leadership from Douglas Turner Ward, the company's co-founder and artistic director.
LEAD: The Presidential campaign of former Arizona Gov. Bruce Babbitt has had to borrow heavily to stay afloat after a sharp drop in fund-raising this summer.
LEAD: John Van der Wiel has achieved what is surely the greatest success of his career by winning the O.H.R.A. Crown-Group International Tournament in Amsterdam.
LEAD: Japan this week begins the formal process of choosing its next Prime Minister to lead it at a time of mounting overseas pressure to play a more vigorous global role.

LEAD: The sole survivor of a shooting that killed seven relatives was charged today with murder in the slayings. A 14-year-old family member who was among the victims had at first been blamed for the deaths.

LEAD: THE search for a precise way to measure the rate at which the chambered nautilus matures has long frustrated scientists because of the difficulty of studying live specimens of the peculiar shellfish. But with the help of fallout from nuclear bomb tests, biologists have at last tracked the life history of one of the creatures.

LEAD: Gayle Gardner, who has worked as a reporter and anchor at ESPN since 1983, will leave the cable network to work at the same jobs with NBC-TV. On Jan. 1, she will be host of the network's college football bowl coverage. Gardner, 37, will be one of NBC's anchors at the 1988 Summer Olympic Games in Seoul, South

LEAD: Twins born joined at the back of their heads could remain hospitalized for up to six months as doctors deal with post-operative care that is as complicated as the surgery that separated them, doctors said.
LEAD: Two men are sitting in a restaurant. They see a couple of women they know at another table. One of the men gets up, walks over and says:
LEAD: Entex Inc., a natural gas distribution company in Houston, has agreed to be purchased by Arkla Inc. in a stock transaction valued at $25.30 a share, or $572 million.

LEAD: The six Democratic Presidential candidates heatedly debated a wide range of foreign policy issues here tonight, with much of the pressure focusing on Senator Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee and his effort to break apart from his rivals' positions on foreign affairs.

LEAD: DURING recent corporate cutbacks, public relations personnel were often among the targets. Members of corporate listening posts in Washington, where they functioned as lobbyists, lost their jobs. So did editors of employee publications at manufacturing companies.

LEAD: The management of Eastern Airlines yesterday outlined the pay cuts and work rule changes that it says it needs from the machinists' union to bring the pay of its 11,600 members more in line with the company's other unions and to make the airline more competitive.
LEAD: Two University of New Hampshire students who had been charged with rape pleaded guilty to a lesser charge today and received three-month jail terms.

LEAD: Cheryl Pierson being escorted from court yesterday in Riverhead, L.I. She was sentenced to six months in jail for her role in planning the murder of her father, who she said sexually abused her. Page B1. (NYT/Marty Heitner)

LEAD: If the Twins do not win the first two games of the American League championship series in Minnesota, they most likely will be in serious trouble. The Tigers could then conceivably wrap up the playoff in Detroit.
LEAD: Scientists say they have developed a computer program that can predict where most illicit marijuana patches will be hidden, giving law officers a head start on the illegal growers.

LEAD: Prices of short- and long-term debt securities fell modestly yesterday as market participants continued to expect that a strong economy and a more restrictive Federal Reserve policy would lead to higher interest rates.
LEAD: The Supreme Court yesterday let stand a lower-court ruling blocking publication of an unauthorized biography of J. D. Salinger.
LEAD: A 10-hour strike by 50 Amtrak maintenance employees disrupted rail service in parts of New York and New England today before a Federal judge ordered them back to work.

LEAD: Tennis Sweden Gains Davis Cup Final: Stefan Edberg beat Emilio Sanchez, 6-4, 8-6, 6-4, yesterday to clinch the Davis Cup semifinal for Sweden against Spain. The victory puts Sweden into the Davis Cup final for the fifth straight time. Sweden will meet India, which upset Australia in the other semifinal, in December.
